characters: INT. KARENIN'S DRESSING ROOM, SAME TIME--
I BEG YOU TO COME. I NEED YOUR FORGIVENESS.
INT. GUEST BEDROOM, POKROVSKOE, SAME TIME--
SOUND OVER--MUSIC OVERLAP WITH THE BALL.
INT. SITTING ROOM, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--
INT. ANNA'S BOX, OPERA HOUSE, SAME TIME--
INT. TOP FLOOR, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--
FLASH BACK-- SHORT, A BEAT OR TWO--
INT. UPPER LEVEL, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--
INT. NIKOLAI'S ROOM, KHITROVA, SAME TIME--
INT. GOVERNMENT BUILDING, SAME TIME-- DAY
EXT. THE LADIES' STAND, THE RACES, SAME TIME--
INT. SITTING ROOM, POKROVSKOE, SAME TIME--
INT. UPPER STAIRS, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--
INT. OBLONSKY'S DRESSING ROOM, SAME TIME--
FLASH BACK, VERY SHORT, ALMOST SUBLIMINAL--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE--Expert fingers--female, unlovely, capable--shape a dough which, with some shreds of cabbage, becomes a fille which is now placed on a baking tray to join rows of piro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-- One hand opens the oven, and, mittened by an apro a tray of perfectly baked pirozhoki, which the other hand fresh tray . . . slightly burning itself on a knuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agafia sucks her knuckle and checks what's cooking on the the cook-housekeeper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He needs to come in if he's to wash himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Kitchen Maid at the sink obediently dries her hands on dozing dog, Laska, pricks up her ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's snowing. The Kitchen Maid, shawled, with a lantern, across the yard towards the cowshed, a short distance, an frozen door. Laska is at her heels, but is made to stay o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The herd stirs at the lantern light. The bull, Berkut, wi his nose, snorts as the girl goes by. At the back of the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin is midwifing, sleeves pulled back, blood and slime He is 34. His steward, Vasili, holds up a lantern. Levin the emerging forefeet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good girl . . . good girl, Pava.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The calf's head emerges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agafia Mishaylovna says dinner's like to spoil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The calf enters the world like a diver. Levin is feeling pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . her father's colour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worth coming home for, Konstantin Dmitrich!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stayed too long in Moscow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cow nuzzles and licks her calf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleaned up, in a smock shirt, Levin bites hungrily into a He has a book on a book-rest. Agafia ladles soup for him. of family portraits look down on him.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . She's a beauty. That's twelve cows sired by Berkut!  AGAFIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So one of you is doing what the good Lord made you for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin evades, ducks into spooning up soup, finding his pl Agafia goes out. Alone, Levin closes the book and stares

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE--Expert fingers scrape a cut-throat razor across a cheek . . . and again, skirting luxuriant facial hair on   TITLE OVER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a door to the landing and a door to the bedroom.     5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince Stepan Oblonsky-- Stiva to his friends--is 34 and body. A barber comes in every morning to shave him. His v older and almost a friend. He holds up an enormous pear.  MATVEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should I do with this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky puts the barber on hold to have a look.  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you find it?  MATVEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your hat. Your Excellency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky thinks about it, lets the barber finish. He stan dressing gown.  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes . . . I picked it up somewhere for Daria Alexandrovna and the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matvey is ready with Oblonsky's shirt, which he puts over like a horse's collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a sloping lineup of five children, aged eight, f two, dressed and brushed for presentation to their mother Oblonsky, known as Dolly . . . who we now see is heavily ing by is a French governess, Mlle. Roland, and a Nurse. is buxom.    6

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly picks up the youngest, Vasya, to kiss him and hands Nurse, and kisses the others in ascending order.  DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonjour, Lili; bonjour, Masha; bonjour, Grisha; bonjour, Tanya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's coming to see Grandmama?

dialogues.speaker: INT. OBLONSKY'S DRESSING ROOM, SAME TIME--
dialogues.text: DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky, dressed now and holding a cup of coffee, checks   OBLONSKY'S POV--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly, in furs, the four youngest children and the Nurse, all wrapped up against the cold weather, have come out of waiting sleigh, as noisy as starlings, bickering, competi The Oblonsky's Coachman assists, with a rug to spread acr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky hands his coffee to Matvey and lights a small ci to take a sugared almond from a dish of sweets, and leave

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tanya is at her lessons with Mlle. Roland. When Oblonsky' smiling round the door, Tanya jumps up and runs to him, g laughing, kissing his face, hanging on his neck.     7 OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Tanruchoshka! Mind my cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pops the sugared almond into her mouth and puts a cons to his lips. Mlle. Roland, who has stood up for him, cluc  OBLONSKY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be good today. I'm off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tanya runs back to her seat and bends to her schoolbook. Mlle. Roland in the eye. He moves his head slightly, unmi ing her to come outside. Mlle. Roland moves her eyes at h reproach. Clearly, this is familiar ground. Oblonsky clos him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: mlle. roland (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read the chapter carefully. I'll come back to test you on it . . . Read it twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE--Pretty fingers put on several rings, and then pick jade paper-knife to slit an envelope and withdraw a lette   TITLE OVER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is early in the day. Anna's maid, Annushka, has been d Annushka is young, loyal, modest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is at her dressing-table-bureau, which is host to at tographs of a small boy (Serozha) and a child's unframed "Maman." As she starts reading the letter, Anna's eyes fr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky and Mlle. Roland in a passionate embrace, vertic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna turns the page, reads on, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still kissing, Oblonsky hoists up her skirts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna turns to the second page.     9

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky, coming in quietly and late from a night on the dressing room. He stops. He smiles a foolish apologetic s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly is waiting for him, shocked, enraged, holding out a pink paper: a love note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna speaks as in exasperation to a naughty child.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tsk, oh . . . Stiva!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . and Dolly found a note from the governess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is speaking to her husband "confidentially." Karenin drains his coffee cup and hands it (as with Oblonsky and valet, Korney, who bows and withdraws. Karenin continues papers from his desk to his portfolio . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which done, he nods to his private secretary, Mikhail Sly forward to receive it, bows and leaves.   10 KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well . . . ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin is twenty years older than Anna and a senior figu ment. He has an unattractive reedy voice and is pleased w model of probity. He has the habit of cracking his knuckl  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stiva wants me to come to Moscow . . . to persuade Dolly to forgive him.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm to be deprived of my wife so that adul- tery may be forgiven? I can't excuse him just because he's your brother.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's for Dolly's sake too.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (has to go) I have four committees today . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is another interruption: Serozha, aged seven and a tutor, Vasily Lukich, enter for a ritual "good morning." frightened of his father, but the mother and son are in l straight to Serozha, her heart lifted, to hug him.  KARENIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, good!--I have the world waiting for me, there's never time to look at your exercises!     11 LUKICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergei Alexeyich is doing very well, Your Excellency.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a button missing) Tsk-tsk, who put this shirt on you? Never mind. I'll come and hear you read.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, perhaps. Thank you, Lukich-- perhaps tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lukich bows. Anna goes with Serozha, relinquishing him fi the door on them.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexei, do you think nine years of mar- riage and children should count for nothing against a . . . an infatuation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin cracks his knuckles, concedes.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Very well. (kisses her hand) But sin has a price, you may be sure of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOUSE--DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky has been bunking down on his couch. He moans and gets up and tries the door to the bedroom. It's locked. H    12 OBLONSKY (PITEOUSLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly . . . please think of the children . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He listens hopefully. The other door, leading to the uppe violently by Dolly.  DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think of the children! Their lives are ruined now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slams the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky comes out of his dressing room to see the main b slammed. He attempts to go in but the door is locked.  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Dolly . . . I beg you . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matvey come to the top of the stairs with a telegram.  MATVEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Telegram. Should I send up the barber?  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, just the razor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky tears open the telegram.     13 MATVEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, sir, things will shape them- selves, you'll see.  OBLONSKY (RELIEVED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sister Anna's coming tomorrow. We're saved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inner doors open and Oblonsky comes out of his private of genial self. Everyone in the general office-- minor offic up for him and bows. Oblonsky is wearing government unifo coat with gold embroidery on the collar--instead of his o is helped out of one coat into the other.  DOORKEEPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some man came without an appointment, Your Excellency . . . waiting outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky opens the door to look. Levin is sitting waiting ing a sheepskin coat, cap and scuffed boots.  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin! Where did you disappear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seizes Levin and kisses him.  LEVIN (NERVOUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very anxious to see you. I need your advice.    14 OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then, come into my room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky leads Levin back through the general office, whe up again. Levin's sheepskin and boots attract curious gla  OBLONSKY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my oldest friend, Konstantin Dmit- rich Levin! Someone send word I'll be a few minutes late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky leads Levin inside and closes the door.  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been hard at it. Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin undoes his coat and sits down.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard at what exactly?  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, we're overwhelmed with work!  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh--paperwork.  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paperwork is the soul of Russia. Farming is only the stomach. When am I going to come and shoot some snipe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeing the clothes Levin is wearing, he laughs.   15 OBLONSKY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but look at you, in Western clothes you told me you'd never wear again. Some- thing's up.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm in love. I've come back to propose. Have you guessed who she is?  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rolls his eyes comically) I have a suspicion. Why didn't you propose when you were here?  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I decided it was impossible. Kitty is of the heavens, an angel, and I am of the earth-- but then I thought and thought, and . . . there's no life for me without her! . . . Do I have a chance?  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you do. The Shcherbatskys are giving a soiree this evening. Get there early before the crowd. If I may suggest . . .  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything! What?  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New boots.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Anything else?    16 OBLONSKY (HESITATES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd better have dinner together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, we'll meet later at l'Angleterre. Or do you prefer the Hermitage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky ushers Levin back into the general office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . Everyone stands up as before. The Doorkeeper produc coat and helps him into it.  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No--five-thirty at l'Angleterre--I owe them more than the Hermitage, so it wouldn't be fair to withdraw my custom. (taking his hat) Boots, and a coat. And a proper hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ushers Levin out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Firstly, a Moscow street scene, busy with people going ab on foot and in conveyances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Secondly, Levin approaches L'Angleterre in his new fur-co hat and boots.     17

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky and Levin preside over the debris of three dozen champagne in a bucket to hand. Oblonsky is in a maudlin m on champagne.  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so unfair. You marry for love, you're a good husband. Children arrive. Years depart. And all of a sudden your wife is tired, her hair is thin, her body . . . while you yourself still have your . . . vigour . . . and you find yourself distracted by a pretty woman . . .  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, but I find that incomprehen- sible . . . As though I'd leave this restaurant and steal a roll from a baker's shop.  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know, a freshly baked roll . . .  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm talking about love, and you're talk- ing about . . . your appetite.  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easily confused. Now look, do you know Count Vronsky?  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? No. Why?    18 OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's your rival. He turned up from St. Petersburg after you left.  LEVIN (AGHAST)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is he?  OBLONSKY (CHANGING TACK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to worry about him. He's one of those rich, good-looking cavalry offi- cers who've got nothing to do but make love to pretty women . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A waiter arrives to remove the oyster shells, while an El a bowl of soup in front of Levin and a lobster in front o  OBLONSKY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cabbage soup?  ELDERLY WAITER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Potage aux choux a la Russe, as the gentle- man ordered.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what I wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky laughs. The Waiter departs.  LEVIN (CONT'D) (ANGRY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Understand that for me, tonight is a ques- tion of life and death.    19 OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Kostya! Kitty would be mad to refuse you. And Dolly is on your side, you know. She says her sister Kitty was always meant to be your wife and will be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin jumps up in elation, collects himself, and sits.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly said that? I've always thought your Dolly's a gem.  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, she is, she is . . . (THOUGHTFULLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved her to distraction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little out of focus and further obscured by puffs of st of a locomotive and its tender plus a carriage or two, wi superstructure--the whole kit and caboodle turning out to table-top model railway--go by the Camera like a WIPE rev momentarily gigantic face of Anna . . . who is crouching the toy go by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serozha is at present snivelling.  SEROZHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why?    20 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because that's where Aunt Dolly lives.  SEROZHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why?  ANNA (PATIENTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, Serozha. She's not well. I must go to see her.  SEROZHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, don't make Mama cry. I'll be back before you know, and bring you a present.  SEROZHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't want a present. I want you to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is on the brink of tears.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh . . . my little Kutik . . .  SEROZHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What present?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She dabs her eyes.     21

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kapitonich, the Karenins' Hall Porter, an "old soldier," house to where a private carriage is waiting. The coachma Anna comes out with Annushka, who has a large soft bag co everything her mistress needs for the journey. Kapitonich door for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna has a window seat. Next to her is Annushka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the opposite window seat is Countess Vronsky, at sixty keep her youthful beauty. She has a lap dog (and perhaps walking cane). Next to her is her Maid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is not happy to be leaving. She holds a small framed zha, which she then puts away in her red bag. Countess Vr her. Anna wipes her eyes, explains.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the first time I've left my little boy.  COUNTESS VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you are leaving your son and I am return- ing to mine. I am Countess Vronsky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna knows the name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: countess vronsky (cont'd) I've been in St. Petersburg for the christen- ing of a granddaughter--my elder son mar- ried Princess Chirkov. You're a charming creature. Why don't I know you?   22 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been in Moscow society, really.  COUNTESS VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you know my name?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard you mentioned . . .  COUNTESS VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talked about, you mean. Ah, love!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, found out, smiles tentatively.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it love?  COUNTESS VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always. My sons are ashamed of me. But I'd rather end up wishing I hadn't than end up wishing I had--wouldn't you?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I . . . I don't know . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna looks at the snow on the window. She is unsettled by

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sleigh (i.e., a cab) brings Levin.     23

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAME TIME--NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hall Porter lets Levin into the house. A Footman take and coat. Levin is uneasy--he seems to be first to arrive come too early. He pulls his coat back from the Footman.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come back.   UP ABOVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princess Ekaterina (Kitty) Shcherbatsky is eighteen. Eage arrived, she hurries from the direction of the reception into the entrance hall in time to see Levin snatch his ha Footman.  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Konstantin!  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm too early.  KITTY (PLEASED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Come up!   DOWN BELOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty runs off out of Levin's view. He flings his hat and man and runs up the stairs.     24

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAME TIME--NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin hurries in and finds Kitty seated prettily in a "re is alone.  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me! I'm receiving for Papa and Maman who are late to dress. It's my first reception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin plays along, kissing her hand elaborately.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princess Ekaterina! Delighted, delighted!  KITTY ( FORMAL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so pleased you were able to be with us, Konstantin Dmitrich!  LEVIN (DROPPING IT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty . . . you look . . . you look--  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stiva told us you were back. How long are you staying?  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. It depends on you.  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On me?    25

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has got ahead of himself. Doors are flung open and the Princess Shcherbatsky, and a crowd of guests who have arr greeting each other. Levin has to make a quick decision, wrong one--to go on.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I mean to say--I came with only one purpose--I want to--will you be my wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty panics. A wave of Guests is almost upon her.  LEVIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry--sorry--wrong moment--but will you?  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty flees. Levin seems stunned, surrounded now by greet and servants with trays of drinks.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It was impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince and Princess Shcherbatsky receive a young married set, Countess Nordston . . . and introduce Levin, who hea ing. He turns away, leaving the Countess hung out to dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin finds himself face to face with Burisov, a silky Of uniform, who introduces himself.  BURISOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burisov. Are you the brother of Nikolai Levin?    26 LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  BURISOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in Moscow, he's staying at the Unicorn in Khitrovka.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?  BURISOV (SMILES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the sort of thing I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bows to Levin and turns away to greet someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin reacts, decides to leave. He makes for the door. He with someone, gives and receives an apology, and suddenly this man in Guards uniform must be. Levin turns.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Count Vronsky?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin pauses awkwardly. Vronsky hesitates, bows and conti witnesses Kitty seeing Vronsky approaching, and sees her Vronsky kisses her hand.  VRONSKY (CONT'D) (BANTERING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princess Kitty . . . It's been so long, and yet it seems like yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His banter is lost on her. She laughs happily.   27 KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was yesterday!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin turns away and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin comes out of the grand house where several coaches bled and angry with himself and the world, he takes off h considers putting his fist through it, but jams it back o cab comes along. Levin waves it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mean street, an area of poverty and crime. Levin pays o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin goes up a dimly lit, dingy staircase. Snatches of M ING drift up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin knocks at a door, then louder. The door is flung op Levin is the spirit of consumptive, bohemian radicalism. surprised.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Kostya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai roars with laughter which turns to wheezing.   28 NIKOLAI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, look at him! You look like a capitalist! (THEN SUSPICIOUSLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. I came to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai goes back into the room, shouting for "Masha." Le

dialogues.speaker: INT. NIKOLAI'S ROOM, KHITROVA, SAME TIME--
dialogues.text: NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin sees that he is in a tiny apartment. A Young Woman fearfully from the inner doorway.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, miss . . . madame . . .  NIKOLAI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk to her like that. It frightens her. You sound like a magistrate. (shouts at her) More vodka for my brother, quick about it.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masha goes to Nikolai and whispers to him, calming him.  NIKOLAI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fills a wineglass with vodka and gulps it greedily.   29 NIKOLAI (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you where to find me?  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A colonel in the Third Department. They're watching you.  NIKOLAI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. They must think I'm dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin involuntarily smiles at the self-puffery.  NIKOLAI (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you got to smile about?  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  NIKOLAI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. The day is coming. I gave up my birthright for it. You're on the wrong side of history. Not because privilege is immoral but because it's irrational.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheezing, he goes for the bottle again. Masha tries to ta appealing to Levin.  MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is sick.  NIKOLAI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let go or I'll beat your lights out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes her away and pours himself more vodka.    30 NIKOLAI (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took Mary Nikolova from a brothel but I consider her my wife. If her presence offends you you're free to leave. Are you married?  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  NIKOLAI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Are you waiting to fall in love?  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  NIKOLAI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Romantic love will be the last illu- sion of the old order. You should marry one of your peasants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin's reaction is almost violent, surprising Nikolai.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I damn well should!  NIKOLAI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (toasts, casually) The brotherhood of man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin recovers himself. He takes out his wallet.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai, you have to see a doctor. Then come and stay with me at Pokrovskoe till you get your health back.    31 NIKOLAI (SCORNFULLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With my wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin becomes flustered.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you . . . or go abroad to a spa. I'll send you more if that's what you . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masha reaches for the money Levin has put on the table. N her hand away. He throws the banknotes at Levin. He cough a paroxysm. Levin tries to embrace him. Nikolai throws hi  LEVIN (CONT'D) (CRIES OUT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the brotherhood of brothers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masha snatches up the banknotes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a scattering of people of all classes on the pla arriving train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the entrance/exit gate, a Guards Officer stands holdin Stationmaster stands by. A strip of faded red carpet has planks.  STATIONMASTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The private coach will stop opposite the carpet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guards Officer nods. He sees Vronsky arriving.   32 VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, what's this?  GUARDS OFFICER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Austrian royalty on their honeymoon. I've got them for four days.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad luck. What do they like? Art?  GUARDS OFFICER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Food.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky moves closer to the slowing train, scanning the w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guards Officer and the Stationmaster are disconcerted "private coach" stop seriously short (or long) behind lug  STATIONMASTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurries away towards the engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky hurries through, relieved not to be late.    33

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky is saluted by his mother's Major Domo, a tall man a cockade.  MAJOR DOMO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second carriage, Your Excellency. I'll see to the Countess's luggage and bring it on to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky nods, and makes his way towards the second coach, flow of disembarked passengers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stationmaster speaks to the Engine Driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guards Officer with the bouquet stands uncertainly wh passengers go past him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Royal Austrian Honeymooners peer anxiously through th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Countess Vronsky remains sitting. Annushka packs away Ann and pillow. Anna looks out of the window.    34 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna moves to the door opening on to the "porch." Vronsky of entering. He steps back to allow her by. They barely e as she passes him, but, simultaneously, each of them look away quickly. His look lingers before he turns away to en

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, from her vantage point spots Oblonsky, calls to him with her bag, comes onto the porch and descends to follow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna steps down to the platform and embraces Oblonsky. Th to see each other.  ANNA (ACCUSINGLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't look ashamed.  OBLONSKY (CONTRITE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am, I really am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Countess Vronsky remains in her seat. Vronsky bends at th ing at Oblonsky and Anna.     35 VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. Oblonsky's sister . . . Karenina.  COUNTESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charmante, don't you think? (to her Maid) Wait for me in the carriage. I'll take Tosca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the dog. The Maid leaves with her bag.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . You stayed longer in St. Petersburg.  COUNTESS VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long enough for you to start a little love affair, I hear.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't think what you're referring to, Maman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances back to the window, where Anna turns back to e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Anna turns back, a Railwayman with a hammer for tappin is in her way. He steps back for her with a bow and a "Ma glances at him and moves past him. The man taps a wheel, ing sound which means the wheel is okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Anna mounts the steps, a Train Guard looks up and down form, holding a green flag.    36

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna enters from the porch.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, Countess, you have found your son and I have found my brother.  COUNTESS VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame Karenin has a son, too. It's the first time they have been apart, so she frets about him.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me for not recognizing you before.  COUNTESS VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We passed the time telling each other about our sons.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I've been hearing all about you.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That must have been very boring for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ringing sound of the wheel-tapper's hammer is faintly Anna's hesitation. Anna shuts off the gallantry.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Au revoir, Countess.  COUNTESS VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Au revoir, my dear. Let me kiss your pretty face.   37

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Countess Vronsky does so. Anna turns to offer her hand to Vronsky takes her hand, the train lurches and moves, unst both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky-- and everyone still on the platform--is shocked scream and shouting. The train, having moved a few feet, hurries towards the scene of the accident, right opposite master overtakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Wheel-Tapper lies between the wheels, mangled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky joins the horrified onlookers. The Guards Office with his bouquet. Then Vronsky arrives. He turns to the G  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your people inside until this has been cleared up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Countess Vronsky, Vronsky, Anna and Oblonsky, Oblonsky al come towards the gate. A Porter follows with Anna's large boxes, etc. Annushka has the travelling bag.  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . the sole support of a large family, they say.    38 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't anything be done for them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky glances at her.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait for me, Maman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky retraces his steps.  COUNTESS VRONSKY (TO ANNA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've you to thank for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knows her son. Anna hasn't understood, but when Oblon he sees Vronsky with the Stationmaster, taking money from  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a good fellow . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna catches on, doesn't like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you known Count Vronsky long?  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you like him? He's in love with Kitty.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh . . . (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we should be discussing you and Dolly.   39

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She scolds him like a naughty boy.  ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you got to say for yourself?  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've said it all--on my knees--in tears . . . Now I need you to say it. I'm going to the office, so you'll have Dolly to yourself.  ANNA (SEVERELY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be home late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOSCOW--DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly pours tea for Anna. Dolly smiles at her wanly-- bri  DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty's coming by to see you. She's all grown-up, and a bit frightened of you--the belle of St. Petersburg society!  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that who I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly . . . Stiva has told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly bursts into tears. Anna embraces her.  ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly, I'm sorry from the bottom of my heart.   40 DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what to do.  ANNA (SOOTHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know.  DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't bear to be with him. And he doesn't care, he's got what he wants.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What he wants is you. He loves you, Dolly. You and the children are everything to him.  DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we? And there is room for a governess?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was shameful, disgraceful. But it was not love. It was the animal in man, not the soul. Stiva's remorse is from the soul.  DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about me? Does his remorse make it easier for me?--  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you are suffering. But, Dolly, you must tell me . . . is there enough love left in your heart . . . enough to forgive him?  DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I think of them together, I can't for- give him, no!   41 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My poor lamb. So you'd rather accept your fate . . .  DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My fate? (OUTRAGED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I haven't done anything! It's him WHO'S--  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love him, Dolly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly nods tearfully.  ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You love him, and he loves you, but you can't forgive, so your lives must continue like this for ever, with both of you wretched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's winning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, Kitty, Tanya and Grisha are at a handsome card tabl board games, dominoes, cards, etc., are kept. There is a bricks, each with a letter printed in it. They are spelli alphabet bricks. Grisha is on Anna's lap pulling at her h business, including misspellings by Grisha, creates a noi mock-rebuke. Tanya at the same time is trying to pull a r finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty is not at all frightened of Anna now; enraptured by    42 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grisha, don't pull so hard, you're getting it all in a tangle--and look for another G for GRIGORI--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (She takes off her ring for Tanya) --here, darling, you can wear it till you go TO BED--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly sits apart, embroidering. She looks up at the sound stairs, Oblonsky coming home. The children hear their fat the card table, running out to greet him. Dolly stands up ferent door, giving Anna a collusive glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna pushes aside the alphabet bricks.  ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's the end of that.  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you stay for the Bobrishchev's ball, Anna?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh . . . I always feel dull at a ball.  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you ever be dull?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky arrives in the doorway with Tanya and Grisha han  KITTY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stiva! Tell Anna she must come to the ball.  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course she must.   43

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cocks an eye at Anna: how did it go with Dolly? Anna m upstairs.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . and God go with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty catches the moment.  OBLONSKY (LEAVING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can introduce me to your new governess.  TANYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's old! She's a hundred!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which leaves Anna and Kitty alone.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know why you want me to come. You want everyone to be there because you're sure it's going to be your night.  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's smile is her acting out a mock-mysteriousness.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has moved alphabet letters around to spell out VRONSK at Kitty's tearful, joyful nodding, genuinely happy for K  ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, to be your age again . . . surrounded by that blue mist, like mist on the mountains   44

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: that clears slowly to reveal the terrifying, beautiful valley you must enter to become grown-up . . . I was eighteen too, when I got married . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quiet note of regret hangs in the air between them for Anna dispels it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With only a lamp or two lit, and the door open, Anna sits card table, with a neglected book, one hand playing idly bet bricks. Their pleasant clicks are the only sound as s thought. She closes her book, marking the place. She is g She hears the sound of the doorbell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky has been let in spattered with snow.  SERVANT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . no, Your Excellency . . . He's just gone up. . . . The Princess retired early . . . Is there a message?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky glances up and sees Anna looking down. Their eyes passes. Vronsky is about to speak. Anna turns away and mo view, towards further stairs, with her book.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.    45

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin is coming home in a sleigh, driven by his one-eyed He is huddled under a bearskin blanket. The house is in s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sleigh overtakes a Peasant Woman, Serafina, walking t rying a big bundle of willow wands strapped to her back: woman with a handsome face. She stops and bows her head. her. She then looks him in the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laska, barking joyfully, races from the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bathhouse has a stove which heats water. There is a b instant steam, but not now. Levin, almost naked, lies on thoughtful, staring at something . . . no, at someone: Se ting on her clothes. Postcoitum. She has no angst. Dresse  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you go to confession?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serafina nods indifferently.  LEVIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God will forgive you.  SERAFINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you also, master. He is watching.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God forgive us then, for committing the act of love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods without irony.   46 SERAFINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is merciful.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Not according to my deserts, O Lord, but according to thy mercy"--that's a fine prayer. But I'm full of doubt. Sometimes I even doubt that God exists.  SERAFINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can there be anything if God didn't make it?  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. One day science will tell us.  SERAFINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's sinful talk if the priest heard you.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I won't go to confession.  SERAFINA (SHRUGS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father built the church. You're con- fessed a while yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin feels outplayed.  SERAFINA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you bring me something from Moscow?  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you like?   47 SERAFINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soap, the kind wrapped in paper to look pretty, and smelling like for a proper lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin is touched. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty enters the Ball, a proper lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a gilded affair, conducted by a Master of Ceremon and Hostess are positioned to welcome each guest. Dancing waltz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty and her parents enter the ballroom and are received Everything has come together for Kitty--her dress, her ha moment. She radiates happiness. An Officer stands aside t openly admiring Kitty, smoothing his moustache. A Youth h with his white tie hurries past but turns back to Kitty.  YOUTH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty! May I have a waltz?  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may, Boris. I'll save you the third just because it's your first ball.  YOUTH (THRILLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're my first conquest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Master of Ceremonies, Korsunsky, arrives and without sweeps her into the waltz.   48 KORSUNSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a relaxation to dance with you, Princess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty sees Anna arriving with Oblonsky and gives a little God-given beauty.  KORSUNSKY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But back to work! Where do you want to be taken?  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Korsunsky waltzes her brilliantly through the dancers and rest in front of a small group including Anna and Oblonsk Kitty's train.  KORSUNSKY (BOWING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that your ankles may be seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna appraises Kitty at a glance and gives her a tiny nod marks. Kitty glows.  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you, Stiva?  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks to Anna, I am a happy man. Would you like to dance?  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, ask Anna.     49 ANNA (DEMURS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No . . . I don't . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up and sees Vronsky coming straight towards her  ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as Vronsky is about to bow, she takes Oblonsky's arm her away. Kitty smiles for Vronsky but his eyes have foll ing she cut him. He remembers himself after an awkward hi mother and father are watching from afar. Vronsky obliges into the waltz.  PRINCE SHCHERBATSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . this vile, idiotic matchmaking of yours . . .  PRINCESS SHCHERBATSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For goodness' sake, what have I done?  PRINCE SHCHERBATSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin is a thousand times better than this Petersburg fop. If he had royal blood my daughter wouldn't need him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky's mind is absent and the waltz ends after only a stand waiting for the music to start.  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is anything the matter?     50 VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You look . . . as lovely as ever, Princess Kitty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music starts and they dance on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of the waltz, Vronsky leaves Kitty with her mo departs. Princess Shcherbatsky is beginning to have doubt  KITTY (SHARPLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ask me, Maman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris the Youth pops up to claim his dance. Dancing, Kitt talking to a couple of Officers. She is anxious but not d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grumpy Prince Shcherbatsky is dancing with Countess Nords  COUNTESS NORDSTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll dance the mazurka with Kitty, you'll see. I call the mazurka the now-or-never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna watches the dancing. She rejects an offer with a smi sky and to her discomfort Vronsky looks up and catches he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns away at once, and notices that ladies are curts bowing as the Host and Hostess escort an overweight but g couple towards a decorative buffet in an adjoining salon: royal honeymooners . . . attended by the Guards Officer f Anna stands and curtseys as they pass by into the salon . is roaring with laughter, champagne in hand.  AUSTRIAN PRINCESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . we were shut up in the train for an hour!    51

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna steals a sidelong glance towards Vronsky but he is n She looks for him among the dancers, smiles at Kitty goin enthusiastic, inexpert Boris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Vronsky is at Anna's side.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dance with me.  ANNA (CALMLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not used to being spoken to like that by a man I met once at a railway station.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dare say, but if I'm not to dance with you, I'm getting out of this operetta and going home.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, for Kitty's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty looks for Vronsky, can't see him, then is taken aba Anna. Kitty watches Anna dancing. Anna says something whi Vronsky laugh. Anna laughs. Anna blossoms in front of Kit sky twirls Anna around and she comes smiling into his arm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It goes on like that. Kitty watches them from within the old men, from the wall. Anna and Vronsky dance slow, they gaily, solemnly, gazes locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Others are noticing too: Countess Nordston, Princess Shch eagle-eyed matrons. Anna, oblivious, has found a release   52

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Countess Nordston finds Kitty sitting alone. Korsunsky an Mazurka.  COUNTESS NORDSTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not dancing the mazurka? I won't have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls Kitty to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: countess nordston (cont'd) I'm engaged by General Glub--I give him to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Korsunsky supervises a large circle of couples who change round, with one couple dancing in the middle of the circl  KORSUNSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . the lady chooses a lady and a gentleman . . . !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lady in the middle beckons to Anna and the man who, c ners, happens to be dancing with her. They enter the midd have their solo turn as a couple, while the original coup ference. Anna is flushed with pleasure. Among the surroun Vronsky has no eyes for his partner, only for Anna. Kitty Vronsky incredulous.  KORSUNSKY (CONT'D) (ADDRESSING ANNA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . and the lady chooses a lady and a gentleman . . . !    53

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna looks smilingly around the dancing circle and sees K at her. Anna "wakes up." Everything which made her drunk sober in the instant. She waits until the change of partn and Vronsky together. She beckons them into the middle. H expects to re-join the circumference with Anna, but she m and escapes through the circle, running towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a howl and clatter, the St. Petersburg express seems the ballroom.   MONTAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An abstract, nightmarish, discordant noise of clattering accompanies unexplained flame--light on wood, glass, iron opens like a door on a blizzard of light, and slams shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's face, eyes closed, floats ghostlike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna comes to consciousness in the dimly lit carriage, ma seems like a hallucination. Wind and snow batter on the w Carriage Stoker, in long coat and cap, deals with the sto a thermometer on the wall. He leaves, opening the door to and slamming it behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train "speeds" (35 m.p.h.) through a blizzard.     54

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna has a reading lamp hooked over her armrest, and a no a page with a paper-knife. But the book cannot hold her. without taking it in. She turns back a page and tries aga once she turns to the window where the dark reflection of at her. Kitty's face staring as she stared at Anna, betra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna turns away from the window. The Guard comes through letting in wind and snow, and shuts it. He walks through  GUARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bologoye! Fifteen minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train is slowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train clanks to a halt at a small station. Anna (and get down from the train. She wears a heavy cloak. The win snowflakes through the station but the roof keeps off the the fresh air. Here and there, men are walking, smoking, She feels better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tall outline of a man in a greatcoat and military cap e flickering gloom. She catches her breath. He salutes her.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I be of service to you?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know you were . . . Why are you leaving?    55 VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know why. I have to be where you are. I can't not.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is wrong. If you're a good man, forget everything that happened, as I will.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll never forget a single thing about you, not a word, not a gesture--  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She climbs the steps on to the porch. At the door to the The encounter has left her feeling elated and frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train arrives. Vronsky gets down from the train and s towards Anna's carriage. His German valet, Franz, runs up second class).  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take the luggage home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz runs back the other way. Vronsky walks on, then sto sees Karenin waiting on the platform, smiling and going f Anna down the steps. Kapitonich enters the carriage. Vron  ANNA (ANXIOUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Serozha all right?   56 KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, is that all I get? Yes, he's quite well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky steps forward. Anna knows he's there. She angles looking at him.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you have a good night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bows to Karenin.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, quite comfortable. Count Vronsky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin extends a hand indifferently then dismisses Vrons Anna with him.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to get back to the Committee . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks Anna away.  KARENIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well--were you a success?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I? Oh--Dolly and Stiva . . . yes, I think so . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky watches them go.     57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A snowy St. Petersburg street. Vronsky arrives home by ca in an old apartment block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky rings the doorbell. A Servant opens the door. A m "If it's someone demanding money, don't let him in!"  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll announce myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Veronsky enters the main room. The occupant of the flat i ant, Petritsky, wearing his greatcoat over shirt and trou  PETRITSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky! The master himself. Baroness, coffee from the new coffeepot for Count Vronsky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Petritsky indicates a pretty young woman in satin.  PETRITSKY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you are pleased by this ornament to your quarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky bows and kisses her fingers.  BARONESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be off home if I'm in the way.    58 VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're at home where you are, Baroness.  BARONESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah!--Pierre, you never say such pretty things to me. We were just discussing my husband. He won't divorce me, you see. And do you know why?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  BARONESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he likes eating off my family silver.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.  BARONESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to bring an action. Just because I'm supposed to be unfaithful, I don't see why I have to eat off Pierre's crockery. Look at it.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my crockery.  PETRITSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was Moscow?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Provincial.     59

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, her dress changed, lies on Serozha's bed, on her si his bedclothes scratching his back gently. He lies quietl with his eyes closed, his face inches from hers. In the d light she gazes at him for long moments.  SEROZHA (MUTTERS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She resumes scratching. He grunts contentedly.  SEROZHA (CONT'D) (SLEEPILY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for my present.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sssh . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him and continues to lie there, gently scratch asleep. She removes her arm and restores his bedclothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a suite of rooms: the Bedroom connects to Anna's Room; and thence to Karenin's small Sitting Room/Dressing connects to the rest of the house. The rooms--like the wh by gas lamps but also by candles at key points.     60

dialogues.speaker: INT. KARENIN'S DRESSING ROOM, SAME TIME--
dialogues.text: NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Korney, the Valet, gathers up a discarded shirt, etc. Kar gown is reading in a comfortable chair, by a candle lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is at her bureau. She frowns and tears up the letter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin looks at the clock-- nearly midnight-- and closes blows out the candle. He comes to the boudoir announcing smile.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time for bed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin comes to put his hand on Anna's shoulder.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm writing to Dolly . . . and to Kitty.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are . . . good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna shakes her head and clasps his hand.     61

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candles each side of the bed. Karenin cracks his knuckles drawer and opens a tin box lying in the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, disrobing, registers these sounds.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they saying in Moscow about the new Statute?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What new Statute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin takes a contraceptive sheath, made from animal in usable) from the tin.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The new Statute I carried in Council.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna blows her candle out and gets into bed.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one mentioned it.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes to bed in his nightshirt.  KARENIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here it made quite a sensation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets into bed. Anna waits dead-eyed. Karenin blows his    62

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOSCOW--DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty, a hollow-eyed version of herself, in a demure nigh on a chaise longue with her legs stretched out. The Famil tially removes one of her slippers as though it were an i  FAMILY DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Princess, but I must . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a silver "fork" the Doctor tests the sole of her foo is miserably going along with a farce she despises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Prince and Princess are hovering. The Princess flutte the Prince is in a temper.  PRINCE SHCHERBATSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I the only one who knows what's wrong with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But a Celebrity Doctor, as shiny as his own gold watch wh ing, is bearing down on them, riding over a Footman's att him.  PRINCESS SHCHERBATSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank God, doctor--my friends say you're the only one who can save her!  CELEBRITY DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Possibly, Princess, possibly! At your service, Your Excellencies. Where is the patient?    63

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty is sobbing with shame: the Celebrity Doctor has str waist and is tapping her chest. The Family Doctor can't b himself.  CELEBRITY DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, come, Princess, we are not backward people--I handle naked bodies every day. Deep breath now . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Family Doctor and the parents are in a huddle. The Pr  PRINCE SHCHERBATSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By God. I'll challenge the scoundrel!  FAMILY DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the modern way . . .  PRINCESS SHCHERBATSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Prince) You're not a doctor!  FAMILY DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her symptoms . . . loss of appetite, fast PULSE--  PRINCE SHCHERBATSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, whose pulse wouldn't be fast if some brute of a--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Celebrity Doctor comes briskly out of Kitty's room, c   64 CELEBRITY DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nervous palpitations. We must treat the nerves. A tubercular cavity is suspected, too soon to tell. Soden water every two hours. I must see her again tomorrow. (HE BOWS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince! Princess!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gone. The Prince enters Kitty's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty is humiliated and triple-wrapped against the violat  PRINCE SHCHERBATSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you fret, my little Kate! You'll wake up one fine morning and say to yourself--"I feel well and happy and I'll go out for a walk with Papa!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Prince is mortified when Kitty's sobs redouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The social set Anna now moves in is the brilliant circle to the Court on one hand and to the demi-monde of artists leading light of this set is Princess Betsy Tverskaya, a Betsy's immediate circle includes Tuskevich, her "admirer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna lifts her eyes to see Vronsky in front of her, talki sees Anna and bows. She acknowledges him and kisses Betsy on, studying the next picture. Vronsky watches Anna move an eye at him.   65

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few rows of chairs in someone's reception room, a mixed a flashy pianist . . . Betsy with a "toy" dog on her lap, side, Anna on the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog yaps and sneezes. Betsy hands the dog to Tuskevic exit with the dog. As Tuskevich leaves, Vronsky comes in. She turns back to the piano. Betsy glances at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna and Betsy, on a bright snow-white day, are being dri park in Betsy's smart equipage . . . towards a horseman w them: Vronsky salutes the little carriage as it trots by looking straight ahead. Betsy acknowledges Vronsky's salu  BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to give a small dinner before the opera. Is there anyone you would like me to ask?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes . . . Yes, the Metropolitan Bishop of St. Petersburg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOUSE--NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annushka puts Anna's opera cloak over her shoulders, whil ready with Karenin's cloak and opera hat. Karenin comes d to join Anna. Kapitonich stands ready to let them out.   66 KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Countess Lydia tells me you haven't been to one of her evenings since you returned.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last one was to meet a missionary, the one before was for a lecture on the union of the Greek and Roman churches. (CLIMBS DOWN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry--I know you're fond of her. Come on, or we'll be late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kapitonich opens the door to let them out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a small theatre with a "promenade" area where a g Officers of high and low rank mix together to enjoy the c comedians and the can-can girls. Vronsky is with his Comm Colonel Demin.  DEMIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the thing, Vronsky. A posting has come up and there's a promotion in it for you.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.  DEMIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The garrison in Tashkent.     67 VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tashkent? But . . . I would like to stay in Peter, sir, if you don't mind.  DEMIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind. But your mother . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The can-can music starts up, to many cheers. Demin claps Vronsky is angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An attendant takes Vronsky's coat and gives him a token f a performance going on within, resolving into applause as stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin, an escapee looking at his pocket watch, comes do down past Vronsky, looks back at him for a moment, and co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky enters the box as the performance prepares to res Tverskoy box, occupied by Princess Betsy and her husband, overweight and, strangely enough, looking at an antiquari ing white gloves. Vronsky bows to them and sits down next takes her opera glasses and looks through them at the Kar  BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't come to my dinner.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to see my Commanding Officer.    68 BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "She" didn't come either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky watches Anna through the glasses. Countess Lydia next to her. Lydia is in her forties, sallow, no beauty, and determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . work never ceases for great men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your husband is a saint and we must all cherish him for Russia's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna winces a smile.  LYDIA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you can come on afterwards--Father Kristof's report on the Chinese mission will be with lantern slides.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm expected at the Tverskoys.  LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No doubt, but I'm sure Princess Betsy can wait for you, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna glances at Betsy's box and sees Vronsky there. The o  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. In fact, I think I won't go to Betsy's.    69

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky looks through Betsy's glasses.  BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're caught.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I am becoming ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOUSE--DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Discreet Footmen move chairs to accommodate the guests wh one of the conversation circles that make a buzz in the r the samovar with her little court, including Tuskevich. T the Princess Myagkaya, stout, red-faced, outspoken, and t Lisa Merkalova and "Anna's Friend."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky arrives.  LISA MERKALOVA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, there's a phenomenon, look-- Anna's shadow has arrived before Anna!  ANNA'S FRIEND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Anna's friend . . . but this making-up- one's-mind-to-it in public is not polite to a distinguished man like Karenin.  PRINCESS MYAGKAYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my opinion Karenin is a fool, and Anna is the best of us.    70 LISA MERKALOVA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we all love you for your contrary opin- ions, Princess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky looks around. He knows everybody in the room.  BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexei . . . You look desperate. That's not attractive.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm losing hope.  BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope of what? Persuading a virtuous woman to break her marriage vows?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how is Tuskevich?  BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not attractive either. Besides, I was never virtuous.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No--you're right. She won't come. I'm going home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Karenin coach arrives. It's Anna arriving at Betsy's. house in almost unseemly haste. Several coaches are waiti     71

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky, in a state, lets himself be carried along. Then He puts his head out of the window to shout to the Coachm  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn round!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOUSE--NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna enters. Faces turn to her. She glances around. She k that Vronsky isn't there. Betsy beckons to her across the possessed, smiling, nodding to friends, pressing a hand h offering the other hand to be kissed, glides through a cr  VOICES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't Nilsson glorious? One sees that she has studied Kaulbach, of course . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something Louis Quinze about Tuskevich . . . as if he came with the furniture . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy is smoking elegantly. She kisses Anna.  BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gone. But you're just in time for the surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a series of minor explosions outside and the dar into an illuminated garden lit by fountains of fire, spra guests react with cries of pleasure and applause.    72

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna turns at once to the window near her, puts her face glass, putting her hands to her temples as if to see the   REVERSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her self-possessed face, lit by fireworks, falls apart in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The firework display continues for a short minute and is acknowledges the congratulations and sycophancy which are men come through the room with trays of ices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is still at the window, unaware that there is only d In the room, Betsy notes the oddity: Anna alone with her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna opens her eyes. She is lost for a moment, perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: vronsky (O.C.) May I have the honour of bringing you an ice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna turns, understanding nothing.  VRONSKY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ices are being served.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would prefer to try a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits down. Vronsky takes out a cigarette case. He lig She tries it and coughs.    73 VRONSKY (IN FRENCH)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Courage!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna smiles. Puffs delicately once.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives the cigarette to him.  ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll try another one sometime.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
