dialogues.text: She looks at him in surprise. He dunks the cigarette in a of ice cream.  VRONSKY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as I was thinking your manners have improved since Moscow. You behaved badly, very badly.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who was responsible for that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna gets up and walks over to Betsy's chair.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a cup of tea.   74

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy obediently gets up to fill a cup from the samovar. Anna. This is watched by more than one guest. Betsy hands to Anna.  BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How nice--Alexei Aleksandrevich has arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin enters smiling. Lisa Merkalova and Anna's Friend delicious-malicious moment.  LISA MERKALOVA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure my nerves can stand another Alexei at this moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Betsy and Karenin move smilingly to greet each other, picks up the two women's intimate laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin remains at apparent ease, as though unaware of pe at Vronsky and Anna, and he kisses Betsy's hand. Princess meanwhile gone over to Anna. Anna likes her and is glad o  PRINCESS MYAGKAYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the Schuzburgs asked us to dinner. The sauce was said to have cost a thousand rou- bles, and it was ghastly. We had to ask them back. I gave them a sauce that cost eighty- five kopeks and it was a triumph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna and Vronsky laugh. Princess Myagkaya moves on.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you glad to see me or not?     75 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This must stop. You make me feel as if I were guilty of something.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to go to Moscow and beg Kitty to forgive you.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's not what you want. Moscow? I can do better than that. Tonight I refused a posting to Tashkent. I can change my mind, and you'll never see me again.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you have any thought for me, you will give me back my peace.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no peace to give. There can be no peace for us--only misery or the greatest happiness. You are my whole life now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him and nods slowly, as if in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy diplomatically leads Karenin to Anna.  BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your husband is impossible!-- his opinions are all wrong but he talks so brilliantly he wins every argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna looks up at her, hearing nothing.   76 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She notices Karenin, who kisses her hand. Vronsky acknowl  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called to take you home.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm staying. Send the carriage back for me.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bows to Betsy. Ignoring Vronsky, he turns away.   LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky is with one group of guests, Anna with another. S excited, at a small table, involved in a game of cards-- local applause. She speaks a "must go" to Betsy, and swif

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dressed for outdoors, Anna comes down the staircase. The her, opens the door and signals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Karenin coach moves to the entrance door, which is he Doorkeeper.   77

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna hears hurried footsteps on the stairs. She hesitates towards the door. Vronsky catches up with her. The Doorke door open.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want me to go to Tashkent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two horses are restless in the freezing air. Konrad l Nobody coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--NIGHT  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I'll go to Tashkent.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I don't want you to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and goes out. Vronsky follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky opens the carriage door for her. She gets into th door. He watches the coach go. His face.    78

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kapitonich lets Anna in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOUSE--NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin, reading by candlelight in his dressing gown, hea Anna's return, all the way to her entrance. He cracks his  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting up? How unlike you!  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I stayed up to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna keeps going, to her dressing room/boudoir.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about? It's late. Where's Annushka?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits for her to return without her cloak.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sent her off.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you want to talk, but we should go to bed.   79 KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to warn you about something.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warn me? It's really rather late . . .  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish to warn you that you may inadver- tently, by indiscretion and carelessness, give the world occasion to talk about you.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not a committee. Please say what you want to tell me.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and Count Vronsky attracted attention tonight.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like it when I don't talk to people, and you don't like it when I do.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't notice anything, myself. But I saw that everyone else noticed. I consider jeal- ousy to be insulting to you and degrading to me. I have no right to inquire into your feelings. They concern only your conscience. But I'm your husband and I love you. It's my duty to remind you that we are bound together by God, and this bond can only be broken by a crime against God.     80 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have nothing to say to you, and I'm tired.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you have a son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She returns to the boudoir. After a moment he follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin finds her in her underwear, throwing aside her dr gises for that.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me. (TURNING ASIDE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I am wrong, I ask your pardon.  ANNA (LIGHTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking about, and it's really too late for this. Excuse me, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she wants to undress, Karenin leaves her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna lies in bed next to Karenin, elated.  ANNA (ALMOST INAUDIBLE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late.   81 CLOSE--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the next instant, seemingly in her own bed, she gasps her body has taken a blow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CUTS are now between a fragmented narrative of voraci BEFORE") and "prelude to sex," this being a sequence of s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna arrives, heavily veiled, by cab. She enters the buil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky opens his door to Anna. They don't speak. He take brings her in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky leads Anna through the apartment to the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky takes off Anna's outer clothes, slowly and carefu her hat and veil.   82

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, in underclothes, unbuttons Vronsky's shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna and Vronsky are standing kissing passionately. He ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna ends up half off the edge of Vronsky's bed, climaxin and falling to the floor. Vronsky, also half off the bed, He reaches down for her. She grasps hold of his hand, hud her, distressed to tears.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God forgive me. It's the end of everything--I've got nothing left now, only you. Remember that.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna . . . Anna . . . how can I not remem- ber? You're my happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He draws her back on to the bed, kisses her face, her sho     83 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happiness! You murdered my happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tries to leave but he attacks her as a lover, and she  ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murderer. Murderer. Go on. Go on. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts hitting him.  ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Go on. Go on. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In sunshine, a large chunk of ice loses its purchase on w floating along a stream of tiny ice floes between grassy snow, with early aconites showing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The icy stream flows under a footbridge which has a broke Vasili, the steward, is on the bridge with a Carpenter. L displeased.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought that had been done.  VASILI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave the order. What can you do with these people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin rides on, into an expanded prospect of fields and w   84 LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Levin gets in view of the house, he is puzzled by th a three-horse sledge arriving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The new arrival is Oblonsky, enjoying his food.  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah--potage aux choux a la Russe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agafia comes in with the roast fowl.  OBLONSKY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agafia!--if you opened up in Moscow, l'Angleterre would go out of business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want news of Moscow?  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of Babylon? No.  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, what do you care? You love the country--you've got it. You love agricultur- ing, and, Lord knows, you've got it. You love shooting--you've got it. You've got every- thing you want!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agafia, leaving, throws Levin a look (no wife).  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, go on, then. Have you stopped stealing bread rolls?   85 OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ballet girl, oriental type. How can I help it?  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, nothing new to tell me. How is--how are the Shcherbatskys?  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean Kitty.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I . . . Is she engaged now?  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Vronsky went back to St. Petersburg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits for this to sink in.  OBLONSKY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty will be at Ergoshovo visiting Dolly in the summer. You could . . .  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, as if I had time in the summer! And I've got extra land this year at Kashin for the haymaking.  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kashin? That's on the Ergoshovo road, isn't it? Won't you call when Kitty is there?  LEVIN (HEATEDLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Especially not then. I humiliated myself once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it's a row.   86 OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn you, Kostya, you love Kitty and you can't forgive her because, first, you funked it, then you bungled it, then you ran away from an eighteen-year-old girl who was made a fool of by a uniform. It's Kitty I'm sorry for--not you!  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her heart told her no. Did you come to shoot snipe or criticize me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin and Oblonsky, with Laska, wait with their guns, a f Levin has calmed down.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you, getting married is . . . a social engage- ment. Not for me. For me, it's the condition of personal happiness and living the right way. I'll never again be carried away by passion. I renounce it. I'll have to find another way . . .  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look out--here they come!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of snipe come drumming over the trees. The men f ously. One snipe falls.  OBLONSKY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad luck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky laughs. Despite himself, Levin laughs too. Laska   87

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPRING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly has had her baby. She is holding the infant, having feeding him. Kitty is with her.  DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There. Oh, I'm sore with his feeding! Would you like to hold him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly gives the baby to Kitty, who takes him almost unwil buttons herself. Kitty's maternal instinct won't engage.  DOLLY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't hold him like a parcel . . . It's Aunt Kitty, darling. . . . Little face . . . little fingers . . . look at you . . . Doesn't he make you ashamed of dwelling on your troubles . . . ?  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no troubles.  DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man wasn't worth the tears, believe me.  KITTY (IRRITATED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care about him. I don't even think about him. Or her. Except to hate her.  DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we'll never speak of it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly relieves Kitty of the baby.   88 DOLLY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are better men waiting for you. Stiva says . . . Kitty, my lamb, did Konstantin Levin . . . ?  KITTY ( FLARES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What has Levin got to do with it? Anyway, I'll never get married. The whole business of . . . it's become disgusting to me . . . and look what it's done for you! Why do they call it love?  DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovingly, she settles the baby in his crib, her face fill the bargain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPRING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lovers' idyll, by a stream on a warm day. Anna, lightly a cigarette, watches Vronsky fill his wineglass from a te stream. There is a pony trap which brought them. He comes her. She kisses him.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to. I don't care about it.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should care. You're not supposed to.    89 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pooh! Who says?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody. Doctors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs and throws her cigarette into the stream.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're squeamish. You a soldier! Would you faint?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, someone might be watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna looks all around. Vast emptiness. She lifts a dock l it. She looks up at the sky.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm damned anyway.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not. I'm blessed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna pushes him onto his back and straddles him.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You love me.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only me.    90 VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apart from Frou-Frou.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna holds his face between her hands and works her body  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But me more than your horse?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you happy?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you love me?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna drags the front of her skirts out of her way.   91 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This much?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This much?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This much?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This much? And this much? And this much?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  ANNA ( FIERCELY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And . . . this . . . much . . . ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She falls on him. He strokes her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her hand comes into view, the index finger bloody. She ca lips with it. She kisses his lips clean, and rolls off hi     92 ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So this is love. This.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUMMER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Korney brings Countess Lydia. Karenin comes from behind h invite her to a chair.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Countess . . . I thought you would be at Peterhof now.  LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've come from there. I'm distressed that you haven't taken your usual house this year.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna wanted a change. She is spending the summer at Tsarskoe.  LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near Princess Betsy. And . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin waits.  LYDIA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guards are in summer camp at Tsarskoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin waits.     93 LYDIA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexei Alexandrovich, forgive me but you are too tolerant! Your wife . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin affects surprise.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, is this about my wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles at her.  KARENIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife is beyond reproach. She is, after all, my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Countess Lydia gets the message. She rises to go. Karenin and accompanies her to the door. She leaves him, and his way to his disturbance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Commanding Officer is throwing a party for his office ing, Soldier Servants, a crowded table on the large veran ers in white linen tunics performing operetta and folk so party spirit, is with Petritsky and another friend, Yashv

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An officer we don't know is, surprisingly, hailed as "Vro Vronsky's elder brother, Alexander. He gestures "Later!" sky. The brothers embrace.  ALEXANDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alyosha . . . a message from Maman. Her friend Princess Sorokina has a house here, and a virgin daughter, that's not part of the   94

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: message, but they'll all be at the races and you're expected to supper afterwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The song ends and Demin, half drunk, climbs on the table, and a toast.  DEMIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen--I give you--the regiment!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General uproar. "The regiment."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a garden bench where the noise of the party is quieter Alexander talk.  ALEXANDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you turned down a promotion.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was Maman interfering.  ALEXANDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. And now she's come up with a princess for you. (SERIOUSLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexei--we're brothers, so don't take offence. Getting married puts the pack on your back--it leaves your hands free for climbing the ladder. Getting serious about a married woman is like carrying your pack in your arms.     95 VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they talk about me. I'm leaving, Sasha.  ALEXANDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An assignation?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, I'll introduce you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky with Alexander beside him clucks his tongue at th of a stable and calls softly for Frou-Frou. There's a sti mare's head appears. Vronsky opens the door.  ALEXANDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful. A man would come to no harm. Do you think you'll win tomorrow?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makhotin's Gladiator is favourite, sixteen hands--Frou-Frou looks dainty beside him, but she's got heart. Haven't you, my darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses Frou-Frou.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky sees Anna before she sees him. He pauses to look her beauty, full of love for her. She is lost in thought.     96 VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has not been expecting him. She is concerned.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexei, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head: nothing. She comes to him and hides h breast. He holds her tight, taking her hand and kissing i  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't bear not to see you before the race.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hugs him, kissing his tunic.  VRONSKY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you thinking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She continues to hide her face. He lifts her face.  VRONSKY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky presses her hand to his face.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah . . . My love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her brow and her eyes.     97 VRONSKY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, love was never a game to us. Here's an end to living in corners, existing day to day on lies. Yes, now we can be together.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can we, Alexei?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Karenin everything.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think my husband will make you a present of me?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave him.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave him and be your mistress?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Run away.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would never see my son again. The laws are made by husbands and fathers.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, then? I'll never forgive myself for your unhappiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna looks into his face.     98 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unhappiness? I'm like a starving beggar who has been given food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles rapturously.  ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I unhappy? No, this is my happiness!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TSARSKOE--DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a good maze. Anna and Serozha are running, laughing, hedges. It's a game. She is trying to find her way to him hedge divides them. Serozha darts away from her, runs int doubles back. She spots him, follows him, and now he has

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serozha finds his way out of the maze and is confronted b  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you, young man? Your tutor doesn't seem to be in evidence. We'll have a look at your lesson books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, coming out of the maze, sees Karenin, recovers.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexei!--you got away at last. Can you stay?  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why . . . ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serozha looks scared to tears. Anna kisses him.   99 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go and find Vasily Lukich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serozha runs into the house.  ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to change. Princess Betsy is sending her trap for me. Would you like to come?-- she's taking me to watch the race.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin smiles coldly.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Races, surely. No, I'll come on later, and then I must get back to town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna returns to the house. She wipes her kissed hand on h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a rough-and-ready racecourse but the venue for a sion, with a grandstand for top people and a grander sect for greater comfort, for members of the Imperial family. parade for some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The racecourse itself is an oval approached by a straight fences, water-jumps, etc., of various difficulty. The "jo the Guards, the Hussars and other regiments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Among them is Vronsky, attended by a Trainer who is fussi Frou's bridle and calming her. Vronsky looks with interes ful horse which must be Gladiator, with Captain Makhotin saddle. Makhotin and Vronsky greet each other with a nod.    100 KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- arrives at the races . . . making his way towards the raising his hat to acquaintances . . . his eyes busy look reaches the front and looks up at the Ladies' Stand.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE LADIES' STAND, THE RACES, SAME TIME--
dialogues.text: DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna and Betsy are here, and, not far away, so are Counte the Princesses Sorokina: the mother is a fading fortyish; eighteen, blonde and pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Below the ladies section is a planked standing area for g may stand to watch the races from the stepped aisle of th Soldiers, Horse People and Locals watch from the turf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A race is flowing towards the winning post, with accompan tion, but it is clear from Anna's detachment, exchanging that this is not Vronsky's race.   KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --looks up to the ladies' stand. Betsy smiles at him in g seems unaware.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Countess Vronsky appraises the young princess.  COUNTESS VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exquisite creature . . . you really ought to be the spoil of victory today . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young princess smiles at her. Countess Vronsky turns the Starting Post.   101

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . Vronsky mounts Frou-Frou. The Riders move to the st   KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . watches Anna who is looking through her glasses tow Post while the current race finishes to cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's anxious attention turns to a horse and rider who f down the course-- and to the ambulance wagon (with a red on it) . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin mounts the steps of the aisle, raising his hat to Anna ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the wooden boards below, where gentlemen are watching, up to Betsy.  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princess! A bet! What do you fancy in the next?  BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kusolev.  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on Vronsky. A pair of gloves?     102 BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done! (TO ANNA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander Vronsky . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the aisle at the top of the stand, Karenin watches as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky's brother Alexander, escorting his wife, Varya, b Betsy, but significantly Varya succeeds in not noticing t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The riders line up . . . and they're off.   VRONSKY'S POV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stands and spectators are distant, the first fence co on either side. His neighbour falls at the fence but Frou Gladiator half a length in front. The next fence is comin and Frou-Frou jump cleanly but a following horse falls ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spectators on either side of Anna and those behind and in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna reacts not at all. Her gaze through her glasses stay on Vronsky. Karenin notes this, and from then on his atte Anna. When the horses come opposite the stand, she lowers follows Frou-Frou taking the lead from Gladiator.   103 VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- eases Frou-Frou past Gladiator. The horses take the ne   LADIES' STAND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With one hand Anna grips her folded fan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin's face is a mask as he watches Anna unconsciously it. She raises her glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frou-Frou approaches the last fence with Gladiator half a on the near side to Anna.   VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- working the reins, rising and falling in rhythm with t ahead to the winning post, and before knowing it he makes the rhythm, dropping back into the saddle and raising the as Frou-Frou takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frou-Frou rises, Gladiator rises. Frou-Frou disappears. G the fence in Anna's foreground. Simultaneously, there are exclamations all around her-- OFF CAMERA-- and the view t the glasses zigzags in search of Frou-Frou, impeded by ho fence.    104

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lowers the glasses and sees Frou-Frou on the ground, Vronsky on the ground.   COUNTESS VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- sees this, too, her mouth set tight with contempt.   KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --looks shocked. Almost in the same moment he hears Anna' cry, conspicuous in the hubbub that follows the crowd's e  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexei . . . !  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is adroit. He comes down several steps and pushes th but Anna has lost control, trying to escape like a bird b  KARENIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna ignores him, puts her glasses to her eyes, searching

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky extricates himself from his broken horse and, in tion, tries to pull Frou-Frou to her feet by the reins. F to get up but her back is broken. Officials, officers, an running.   105 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . sees an Officer hurrying to the Imperial party to r  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stiva! What are they saying?  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky's unhurt--but the horse . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna relapses into sobs, attempting to hide her face behi fan. Betsy gives Anna her fan.   VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --is restrained by an Officer.  OFFICER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her back's broken!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Officer takes a pistol from his holster. Vronsky, enr takes the pistol from him.   KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --persists with Anna.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm asking you . . . if you wish to go . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He touches Anna's arm. She jerks it away.     106 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, leave me alone.  BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bring her home, Alexei.  KARENIN (SMILING POLITELY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Princess, but Anna is not well and I want her to come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gunshot is heard from the course. Anna turns her tear-s towards it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's hysteria has solidified into a blank despair. Kare to pretend that nothing important has happened.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know . . . they say the Emperor dis- approves of the races . . . the danger of injury . . . but I . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna looks at him contemptuously.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm saying there is a value in manly sport, for the military--     107 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my opinion, it's not the sport itself that's wrong, it's the spectacle, it's making a cruel spectacle out of--  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin changes tack.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to tell you--  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to tell you, you behaved improperly today.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has raised her voice. He raises a warning finger, and communication window behind the coachman's box.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By making plain your feelings when one of the riders fell. Your conduct was improper. It must not occur again. I have said it before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna smiles faintly. He is misled by that.   108 KARENIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are going to say my concern is unneces- sary and ridiculous. You are my wife. I am wrong to think that . . . yes--perhaps I was mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna looks at him despairingly.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you were not mistaken. I love him. I am his mistress. I can't bear you, I'm afraid of you, I hate you. Do what you like to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin is literally winded--gasping for breath, slowly g ing under control. Anna huddles away from him in her corn recovers himself only to the point of sitting stock-still not moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coach lurches, unbalancing him so that he is pushed a recoils as if from a contamination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coach slows. The coach stops. A Servant comes to the the door.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, please. Move away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Servant backs off.  KARENIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not have a scandal. Therefore . . . You will not see . . . this man again. You will behave in such a way that nothing is known against you, by society or by the servants. In return, you will keep the privileges of a   109

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wife--and the duties. Tomorrow you will return home. That is all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna gets out of the coach and runs into the maze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna comes to Vronsky. She is still shaken by the showdow Karenin in his coach, but is now overtaken by concern for fall.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky shakes his head. He is moved by the sight of her, desire, but in her embrace he detects something new, a ne  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happened?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told him I'm your mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky lifts her face, strokes her cheek. He waits.  ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thinks I can give you up and go on living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He embraces her for that, relieved, grateful, loving--und she is not going to give him up.     110 VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you cannot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imperial hands (the Tsar's for all we know) place over Ka broad red ribbon from which hangs a heavy medal. Karenin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At an ornate doorway a Major-Domo announces.  MAJOR DOMO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their Excellencies Minister Karenin and Madame Karenin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin, wearing his medal, and Anna smile their way into patter of polite applause. Further grandees are being ann applauded . . . Prince and Princess Berghatskoy . . . Amb lain . . . Baron and Baroness Verdlov . . . Prince and Pr  BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexei Aleksandrevich . . . congratulations. You're the only man my husband would do this for.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Prince Tverskoy) Tell me your latest find for your library.  PRINCE TVERSKOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in front of the Princess.    111

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy draws Anna away for a moment.  BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can tell you're happy. You've put on a little weight.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, in the same dress, kisses Serozha tenderly so as no leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna enters the suite where Karenin, in his dressing gown book. He is elated by his evening.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time for bed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is in bed. Karenin is getting ready for bed. Anna li sively to the little noises of Karenin's pre-coital prepa     112 KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . not that I care for decorations but . . .  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexei . . . I can't . . . I'm sorry . . . But I'm his wife now. (she turns to him) I am having his child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin stares at her. He turns back to the open drawer a back the way they were. He locks the drawer. He puts on h and leaves the room. Anna waits a moment and follows him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SITTING ROOM, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--
dialogues.text: NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dark. Anna hears the crack of his knuckles and can s sitting in the dark.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what I did to deserve this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A prospect: next to a country road, a large expanse of me mown forty swathes at a time by forty mowers swinging the in unison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSER--Levin is suffering but keeping up, bathed in pers place is behind an old man, Theodore, who is scything as Just in time for Levin, Theodore calls a halt and takes L sharpen it with a whetstone. Levin attracts a few grins a    113 YOUNG PEASANT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Konstantin Dmitrich, you'll know your rows when the field's all done!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin's row has stalks of differing heights between the e either side. There is some laughter, but the men are unea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time to stop for the day. More tomorrow. The Mowers walk back across the large meadow of cut swathes. From th tion, a crowd of Village Women are coming to meet them ca drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fire has been lit. The Mowers eat their meal in the com Serafina tends to a cooking pot in the firelight. Levin w He has settled down at a discreet distance from the men. is caught by a grown-up Boy and his young Wife who have c slightly apart. He is charmed by them, watching the girl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theodore comes to Levin with a jug. Levin takes a swig.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many mowers is it, Theodore?  THEODORE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-two, master. In your father's time it was work for two days for thirty men . . . (SLYLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . though he never picked up a scythe himself.   114 LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men don't like me for it.  THEODORE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They like what they're used to.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It settles me.  THEODORE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is that, master?  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I'm mowing, I don't ask myself why I'm here.  THEODORE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're here to be master, Konstantin Dmi- trich, to be your father's son, and father to a son who will be master after you, as it has always been by the grace of God.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father owned you, Theodore. My grand- father owned your father. Owned you like chattels, to be bought and sold. Was that by the grace of God?  THEODORE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was. Those were good times when your father had the keeping of us. That's my youngest you were looking at there. His young life is perilous now since the Free- dom came and work must be found.    115 LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true I was looking at him.  THEODORE (LAUGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At his wife too, I dare say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin is abashed, found out.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look happier than I've ever been. Is it living simply that I'm looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night under the stars. Some of the men have gone, some ha the night. The cooking fire is burning out. Levin remains watching, thinking: drawn to "the simple life."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin wakes . . . woken by hoofbeats and the jingle of ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin sees a coach coming towards him. The coach comes ne boxes strapped to the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin sees that a young woman is looking out of the side on to the white ribbons of her bonnet. He sees that it is Ergoshovo. (Princess Shcherbatsky is also inside, dozing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coach passes on, leaving Levin lovelorn, the dawn lig sight of Kitty has turned him round again.    116

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AUTUMN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky stands at the entrance to the platform holding a for a train. He looks pretty fed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As before, the set-up is a small stage, a small auditoriu drinking, cruising, etc., a combination of music hall and tables. Vronsky is here as the escort of a Foreign Prince ing a "risqu" show with Can-Can Girls, much relished by

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky's glance casts about in the gloom. The champagne sky spots a trio--Lisa Merkalova, Betsy, and Stremov, a p Karenin's rival.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky catches Betsy's eye. She beckons him. He excuses Foreign Prince, who doesn't notice, and goes over to the the music, he is introduced to Stremov, and kisses the ha He takes the empty chair.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's some kind of prince at home. Exhaust- ing. Where is Tuskevitch this evening?  BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why ask me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At which moment, Makhotin appears at the table. Vronsky r his chair.     117 VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Makhotin . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky bows to the women.  VRONSKY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must leave you. I'm on duty tonight.  MAKHOTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky woman. Give her my respects, and to Karenin if you see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky freezes in anger.  BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't. Would you compromise me? And Lisa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa and Stremov are enjoying it. Vronsky turns away. The is applauding enthusiastically when Vronsky rejoins him.  STREMOV (SMIRKS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only say that a man who can't govern his wife has perhaps gone as far as he can go in government.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky wakes. He has fallen asleep in his clothes. A not ered, propped up by the bed. He reaches for it.     118

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cab brings Vronsky. The Karenin coach is waiting outsid approaches the door, it opens and Kapitonich comes out wi Kapitonich is wrong-footed by seeing him. Karenin comes o into the gaslight. When he sees Vronsky he hesitates for tinues. Kapitonich is holding open the door of the coach. Karenin, expressionless, touches his hat and gets into th rug. Vronsky walks into the house as the coach moves off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kapitonich comes in, closing the door. Vronsky gives him  KAPITONICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Your Excellency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kapitonich is uneasy. A Footman comes from a service door sky and looks to Kapitonich.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am expected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kapitonich nods to the Footman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, six months pregnant, is seated almost formally. The Vronsky in and retires closing the door. Anna runs to Vro     119 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!--no. I will not live like this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds her, calming her, hushing her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads her into a Winter Garden conservatory off the Re  ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting hour after hour while you're drink- ing champagne with naked actresses-- don't think I don't know!--Lisa Merkalova still calls on me.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's punishment enough that I'm on escort duty, without . . .  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes--I'm sorry--it's my demon, I can't help it.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wrote that you were ill.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I? Well, I am! (GAILY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But don't worry! It won't be for long, I'll soon be out of your way--soon!  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's true. I was told it in a dream.    120 VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, it was only a bad dream.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, and I'm only going to die having your baby.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all nonsense!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him all over his face.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me it is, tell me it is. You love me. Only me.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your note said your husband would be out.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was late. Serves him right. And you. Why do you call him my husband? He isn't my husband--he's a clock, a wooden doll--  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it was awkward . . . a matter of your honour. You made an agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna flares up again.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think of my honour when you're sharing whores with your Hindoo!  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your demon again!   121 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be glad to die, before you start to hate me!  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna gives a gasp. She laughs.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put your hand there. There! Did you feel him move!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Committee" is in session. Stremov has the floor. He map of Russia on an easel, splotched with colours. Kareni listening, his thoughts far away.  STREMOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must respectfully ask Minister Karenin whether his proposals for the regulation of these colourful Gypsy tribes, of these schol- arly God-fearing Jews, and of--but I'm afraid I have lost the Minister's attention . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All turn to look at Karenin, who sits staring at nothing, the pause. He wakes. For a beat he hardly knows where he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kapitonich lets Karenin in. Karenin is brisk.     122 KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is here?  KAPITONICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only Madame, Your Excellency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin goes up the staircase. There is an urgency in him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin walks in and goes to her bureau, empties out litt receptacles, looking for the key to the main drawer. Anna bedroom, alarmed, in her nightdress.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to see him because . . .  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not wish to be told why a woman wants to see her lover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls furiously at the locked drawer, then looks aroun  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you . . . ?  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want his letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin finds an iron bootjack. Anna tries to stop him. H her aside and smashes the wood around the lock, then, str he takes from the open drawer a pretty cardboard box, a g confirms that it contains letters.   123 KARENIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am going to Moscow tomorrow, and then to the provinces with a commission to investigate conditions among the Jews and Gypsies--whose conditions I infinitely prefer to my own. I will not return to this house until divorce has put you into the street. Meanwhile my son will be sent to live with my eldest sister.  ANNA (WAILS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexei . . . please . . . leave me Serozha . . . !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin looks at her with contempt.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I would let you have my son? You are depraved, a woman without honour. I thank God the curse of love is lifted from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks out with the box of letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINTER AGAIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonsky arrives outside his office building in a cab. He

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saluted by the Hall Porter, Oblonsky mounts a semi-grand arrives at the entrance to his department. He goes in.   124

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin stands up in his almost new, hardly used coat, top  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin! What . . . ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin smiles, hopefully, sheepish.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need your advice . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a reprise. Oblonsky understands. He seizes Levin and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small group. Dolly is playing the piano. Kitty turns th The old Prince Shcherbatsky and the Princess are with Cou and Oblonsky.  COUNTESS NORDSTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, is he coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty, keeping half an eye on the door, sees Levin enter turn. Oblonsky goes to greet Levin.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I late? Who is here?  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you're late! Come and meet . . . Countess Nordston.    125 COUNTESS NORDSTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drily, amused) We nearly met at the Shcherbatsky's last winter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin, puzzled, bows to her and to the Prince and Princes tively pleased and making the best of it, and then to Dol  PRINCE SHCHERBATSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come into the fold . . .  DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin is shaken. Dolly leads him to Kitty, who is frighte shamefaced. Dolly leaves them.  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Konsantin . . . what a long time since we saw each other.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since you saw me, but I saw you not so long ago.  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were driving to Ergoshovo . . . I was at Kashin for the haymaking.  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but why didn't you . . . ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are both embarrassed by the wrong step.   126 LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so glad to see you. You're just the same.  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope not--I was young and silly in those days.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Months and months ago!  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you haven't changed.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty looks up at him, decoding. They gauge each other sh  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Permit me to announce--soup Marie Lou- ise, carp with asparagus, and roast beef! I went to the market in person!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Matvey at that moment presents Oblonsky with a visiti salver. Oblonsky reads it.  OBLONSKY (CONT'D) (TO MATVEY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An extra place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The new arrival is Karenin. Oblonsky is pleased.   127 OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin!--I'm glad you came.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been on tour in the regions, a govern- ment commission . . . I'm sorry--I have come to tell you our connection must be severed. I'm going to divorce your sister.  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Divorce? Dear me, what are you talking about? Don't be in a hurry. Stay to dinner and later talk it over with Dolly--  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince Oblonsky, everything is over between our families.  OBLONSKY (REPROACHFULLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexei . . . divorce is one thing but dinner is quite another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner for eight-- clockwise, Oblonsky, Countess Nordston batsky, Kitty, Karenin, Dolly, Levin and Princess Shcherb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Servants and Matvey serve at the table, clearing away asparagus." The Princess is challenging Karenin.  PRINCESS SHCHERBATSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You Petersburgers think yourselves so de bon ton compared with dull, old-fashioned   128

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moscow, but we know how to do things-- only the other day, I hear, Vasya Pryachnikov fought a duel with Kvitsky and killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblonskky attempts to divert the conversation.  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what's this government commission, Karenin . . . ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Karenin ignores him. Oblonsky looks on helplessly.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was the challenge about?  PRINCESS SHCHERBATSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pryachnikov's wife, naturally.  PRINCE SHCHERBATSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a matter of honour, defending a woman's honour . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin remains cool.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounds like barbarism to me . . . And what if the lover had killed the husband?-- would that have preserved the wife's honour too?  COUNTESS NORDSTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, not many of us can say that our lover died for love!     129 KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love? Thou shall not covet thy neighbour's wife.  COUNTESS NORDSTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you die for love, Konstantin Dmitrich?  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would. But not for my neighbour's wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin is nettled to find that he seems to have made a jok especially. Kitty remains serious, watching Levin, loving  LEVIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An impure love is not love, to me. To admire another man's wife is a pleasant thing, but sensual desire indulged for its own sake is greed, a kind of gluttony, and a misuse of something sacred which is given to us so that we may choose the one person with whom to fulfill our humanness. Otherwise we might as well be cattle.  COUNTESS NORDSTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, an idealist!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reconciliatory laughter eases the atmosphere. Levin feels out of his shell. He steals a glance at Kitty and finds h She smiles at him and drops her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dinner party settles in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly and Karenin sit knee-to-knee in a corner.   130 DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . but she will be nobody's wife, she'll be ruined.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to save her. She chose ruin.  DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexei Aleksandrevich--look at me. You will have no peace of mind until you forgive her. It was Anna who taught me that.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not wish to forgive. I am not a cruel man. I have never hated anyone. But I hate her with all my soul for all the wrong she has done me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin and Kitty are at the card table, with a spillage of  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your turn to play us something, Countess.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY AND LEVIN
dialogues.text: LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since we last met, there is something I have often wanted to ask you.  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin sorts through the alphabet pieces as though he is p moment, but he quickly puts four letters spaced out in a   131 LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty tries.  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do Not . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin adds an I next to the D.  KITTY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did. Did Not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin shakes his head. He adds an E next to the second N.  KITTY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last word is Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin nods. Kitty puts letters in place. They read DID NO NEVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin looks into her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty finds letters and presents Levin with T I D N K. Le to the K. Kitty nods. Levin adds OT to the N. Kitty nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin adds an O to the D. Kitty shakes her head. She puts  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what it says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly, looking across the room, sees Kitty and Levin seri rapt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin places extra letters: THEN I DID NOT KNOW. Kitty no   132 LEVIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then. But now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty finds C Y F A F.  LEVIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can You.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty nods.  LEVIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you Forgive. And Forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin puts down I L Y.  LEVIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never stopped . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up to see silent tears streaming down her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin walks away from the Oblonsky house. He lifts his snowflakes. He looks tortured. Snow melts on his face lik from his wallet a telegram.

dialogues.speaker: I AM DYING.
dialogues.text: KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Die, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands in the snow, uncertain.   133

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin sits like a statue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin is let into the house by Kapitonich.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is your mistress?  KAPITONICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Safely delivered of a daughter, Your Excellency.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So . . . she is well?  KAPITONICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mistress is very poorly. The doctor . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin, going to the stairs, sees Vronsky's cloak and ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin comes up the staircase. When he reaches his dress Anna shouting for "Alexei" in her delirium. He hesitates. name again. Karenin enters Anna's boudoir.     134

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin sees Vronsky sitting with his hands over his face up in confusion.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's dying. Please let me stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin looks at him coldly and enters the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is not seeing or hearing, struggling against the Doc wife, while Annushka holds her hand.  DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God! She talks only of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In her delirium, Anna keeps up a bright prattle.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why doesn't he come? He is kind. He will forgive me.  MIDWIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's here--look--look--can't you see him?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want Alexei! Why doesn't he come? Give me some water. No, I mustn't, it's not good for my little girl. Or let her have a nurse. Yes--don't bring her here, because Alexei is coming and it will hurt him to see her.   135 ANNUSHKA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's come, my dear--look there . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annushka gives way to Karenin, who kneels by the bed, tak hand.  DOCTOR (TO ANNUSHKA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annushka hurries out.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, what nonsense. I must be asleep, that's what it is. You think he won't forgive me but you don't know him. No one knows him except me. I'm not afraid of him now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin gazes at her. He looks at her as he's never looke  ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid of death, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin tries to speak but cannot. He starts making shush baby. She quietens down. She seems to recognise him.  ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my dear. Don't look at me like that. I am not the one you think. I'm afraid of her. She fell in love with another man. I'm the real one. But I'm dying now, then she'll be dead, too. Poor man! Let him come in. Alexis! Alexis!     136

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky hears her calling. He comes into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky covers his face, unmanned. The Doctor nods to the "Leave them alone." They leave.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your hands away from your face. Look at my husband. He's a saint! Take his hand. Alexei--take his hands away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin pulls Vronsky's fingers, and holds on to Vronsky'  ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive him, too. Thank God, thank God . . .   DAWN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is asleep. Karenin is alone with her. The crisis see opens her eyes.  ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin puts his face down to her shoulder. She strokes h  ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I had died as I wanted, you would be free of your troubles at last.   137 KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am free of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna closes her eyes and sleeps again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin comes in. Vronsky is there. He looks up abjectly.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you think of me, please believe me, I love her--I could not have done other- wise than what I . . . what I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin nods and sits next to him.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you must leave now. I promise to send for you if she asks for you. I don't know what happened. I forgive you. I forgive Anna. My soul is filled with joy. I will remain with her and look after her for ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin stands up and offers his hand. Vronsky grasps it shaking.  KARENIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come now, come now . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin embraces him, comforting him.     138

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky arrives back at his flat . . . and finds his moth in his sitting room.  COUNTESS VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at you. You look like what you are. A laughingstock. I fancy you are to be asked to leave the regiment.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like you to go, Maman.  COUNTESS VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will go when I'm ready to go. A little affair with a married woman puts a finish- ing touch to a young man's education--but this morbid, selfish obsession . . . ! You have publicly humiliated a man who has devoted his life to Russia, and it will not be forgot- ten. You'd better come back to Moscow with me. You're finished here.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Petersburg? (he taps his breastbone) I'm finished here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time, Vronsky is wearing civilian clothes . ingly at his uniform hanging in his wardrobe. He places h carefully on a shelf and closes the wardrobe.    139

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin is half-dressed in clothes to be married in, assist watched over by Oblonsky, who is in wedding clothes. Levi Oblonsky is perplexed. Matvey is unflappable, holding Lev and following him around.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . no, I'll go to her and tell her it's not too late to stop this business! Better now than when we're married and she realises she doesn't love me!  OBLONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she does love you!  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can she? I mean, look at me! Suppose she's only marrying me to get married? Suppose she's still in love with Vronsky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's making a terrible mistake! I'll go to her and tell her she's free, that's what I must do . . .  MATVEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your coat, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin snatches the coat and puts it on, and dashes out of     140

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin, in disarray, is let into the house. The entrance h and chaotic with children, maids, governesses and Kitty's Masha and Lili are bridesmaids. Grisha is a page. Princes trying to create order among last-minute bouquet distribu adjustments, shoe-changing, etc., sees Levin and explodes  PRINCESS SHCHERBATSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Konstantin!--what-- ?  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to talk to Kitty.  PRINCESS SHCHERBATSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not allowed to see her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin gallops up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty, dressed for the church, is whispering into the cra  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I don't understand at all! What's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't love me. Think it over! Let people say what they like!   141 KITTY ( FRIGHTENED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you mad? Have you changed your mind?  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. If you don't love me.  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I do love you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin hesitates, desperate.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you? Well, I love you!  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Konstantin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They link hands through the opening, each with a hand to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mere fragment of a long and ornate marriage ceremony .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grizzled Priest lights two decorated candles, holding left hand, and he uses his right hand to touch Levin and, Kitty. He gives the couple the candles, Kitty taking hers Levin looks blissfully at Kitty.     142 MIX TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Priest lifts crowns from their heads, and invites the relieving them of their candles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Choir bursts with pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baby girl, two months old, is being fed by a Wet Nurs baby is given over to the Nursemaid who lays the child in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin watches all this. The women ignore him: they are now, and Karenin is harmless. Karenin stares fascinated a stares back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna stares at herself in the mirror. The act of raising an effort. She isolates a thick lock of her hair, and sni

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's hair is short all over. She sits up in bed, listen who has brought the current gossip.  BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . and there was her husband wearing her best ballgown, rouge all over his face . . . ma chere, le scandale! . . . But I'd better tell you some regimental news . . .   143

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin enters and sees a glamorous Footman standing in t hall, holding a white fur cape.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is here?  FOOTMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princess Elisabeth Federovna Tverskaya, Your Excellency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin approaches the bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: anna (O.C.) No--I don't want to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: betsy (O.C.) . . . but your husband surely wouldn't . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna sees Karenin who is about to retreat.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please excuse me.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No--stay.     144 BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so glad to see you. Everyone asks after you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin bows to her and kisses Anna's hand.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look feverish.  BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have been talking too much--so I'm going.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princess Betsy came to tell me . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hide anything from you . . . Count Vronsky asked to come to say goodbye--he's going away. I have said I can't receive him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy kisses Anna.  BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, my treasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin follows Betsy out. Anna gives in to a moment of g herself when she hears the crack of Karenin's knuckles. H  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree with you. As he is going away, there is no need for Count Vronsky to come here.     145 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have just said so, so there's no need to repeat it.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it is for you to decide.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, and I decided.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I am very glad that--  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That we agree, so perhaps we can stop talk- ing about it.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Is there anything I can do for you?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, can you please please please stop crack- ing your knuckles. (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a bad woman. But I can't breathe. Your kindness which I can't repay, and your FORGIVENESS--  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You begged me for my forgiveness.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I didn't die and now I have to live with it! If only you would have gone on hating me.   146 KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then--what? What? What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to see Count Vronsky?  ANNA (QUIETLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to say goodbye.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't hear.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to say goodbye.  KARENIN (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would be lost. Irretrievably lost. You would have no position. And worse if we divorce. You would be the guilty party. That means you cannot legally remarry.
