Your union with Count Vronsky would be illegitimate, and so would your daughter who now has the protection of my name. And that is what you want! It would be a sin to help you destroy yourself.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You forget something. Count Vronsky and I love each other.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this love sanctifies a criminal folly?   147 ANNA (CRIES OUT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I know is that I sent him away and it's as if I'd shot myself through the heart!  KARENIN (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. And Serozha . . . ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the crux for Anna, and she is prepared for it.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would die for him, but I won't live like this for him. When he knows about love, he'll forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin can see where this takes him.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I must choose the smaller sin. Vronsky robbed me of my cloak and I will give him my coat. I will give you grounds to divorce me, and I'll accept the scandal, the humilia- tion and the consequences to my career.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No . . . I can't . . .  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may write to him but I would prefer you not to see him until you have left this house.     148

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two coaches, each with considerable luggage, have a rende on the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is holding Baby Anya. Annushka and the Nurse are wit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky, in civilian clothes, is alone, looking anxiously

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna gives the baby to the Nurse, as the coach halts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna gets out of her coach and runs the few yards to Vron opens the door for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is kissing Vronsky's face and being kissed, weeping,  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like a boy. But so pale. We'll go south . . . to the sea air and sunshine . . .    149

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early morning. In a big untidy bed, Vronsky and Anna lie and satiated. The style of the room, and the warmth of th the journey made, confirmed by the view from the window, panorama from an elevation above the sea. In the room, th unpacked or partly unpacked trunks and cases, and, abando Anna's and Vronsky's clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slyudin is in attendance on Karenin at his desk.  SLYUDIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . and Madame Odette in person, so to speak, Your Excellency, with your permission . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A respectful cough at the door reveals an obsequious male enin is bewildered.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame Odette . . . ?  SHOPKEEPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse the liberty, Your Excellency . . . it's for a bonnet and some ribbons Her Excel- lency has overlooked. If you wish us to address ourselves to Her Excellency, please be so good as to tell us where we might . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin is stricken into immobility, his face hiding in o A tear falls on the blotter. Slyudin rescues him, usherin     150

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Countess Lydia arrives in full fluttering cry.  LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have forced my way in! I have heard!  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Countess, every shopkeeper has heard.  LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear friend! Don't give way to sorrow. Our Lord Jesus Christ has you in his care.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm done for. I don't understand any- thing. All day long I'm being asked to make decisions about bills and servants, the kitchen, Serozha's clothes . . .  LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. I understand everything. I am going to act. The household arrangements you can leave to me. I will come every day. I will be a second mother to Serozha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clasps both her hands and kisses them. Lydia falls to  LYDIA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He that humbleth himself shall be exalted! You must not thank me. Thank Him whose love pours through me!     151

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sleigh brings Levin and Kitty home through deep snow house comes into view.   SLEIGH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have been on honeymoon travels, attested by hotel la gage. Kitty, eager and anxious, looks at the approaching bad. Levin takes her hand. She smiles at him, to calm him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agafia and Vasili come out on the porch. The house has be window frames smartened up, and paper flowers are tied to the porch. The sleigh pulls up. Levin carries Kitty throu porch. Agafia bobs. Vasili bows.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Agafia, and Vasili, the steward . . . My wife, Ekaterina Alexandrovna Levin.  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am very pleased to meet you both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuzma sidles by with a bow and goes to take the luggage f  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that was Kuzma. Come inside!     152 VASILI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful--door's still a bit . . . (to Levin's look) it's all right, it'll be dry tomorrow . . .

dialogues.speaker: INT. SITTING ROOM, POKROVSKOE, SAME TIME--
dialogues.text: DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin shows Kitty in. He is immensely relieved. It never the same time he realises that Agafia is agitated: a word  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty nods, smiles gamely--it's not like home.  LEVIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down a minute.  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No--I want to see everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agafia panics.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin follows Agafia out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agafia follows Levin up the stairs. She is outraged.    153 AGAFIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . and now I'm doing kitchen maid's work because Nadya's parents won't let her set foot in this house, and who can blame them!--it's indecent!

dialogues.speaker: INT. GUEST BEDROOM, POKROVSKOE, SAME TIME--
dialogues.text: DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin enters the small bedroom. Agafia waits outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai is in the bed-- wasted, near death. He lies in sq wiping his face. She stands up at Levin's approach. Levin lai, presses his gaunt hand. Nikolai opens his eyes.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me, Konstantin.  NIKOLAI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, good. The doctor here is useless--get me a doctor from Moscow.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you go? I asked for you every- where, when I was getting married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai sighs and closes his eyes. Levin retreats, looks  MASHA (WHISPERS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry . . . I couldn't leave him. I know I've done wrong.     154 LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. My wife . . . You can't stay now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin goes outside to Agafia and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: SAME TIME-- DAY
dialogues.text: AGAFIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't go against Nikolai Dmitrich's orders . . .  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes--yes . . . She's going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An unwelcome thought strikes Levin.  LEVIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did the doctor see her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agafia nods guiltily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty has remained. Levin, in miserable agony, is sitting hand.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will nurse him with Agafia . . . The woman will find somewhere in the village. You won't see her. She knows it's impossible for you to meet her. It is a torment to me that I have brought you under the same roof   155

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as this unfortunate . . . this fallen . . . and in your precious, in your delicate condition . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty detaches herself abruptly and leaves the room. He h upstairs. After a moment, he follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty comes out of the Guest Bedroom.  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. A clean nightshirt and sheets. A towel and a clean pail of warm water. Ask Agafia for vinegar, and to prepare a bed somewhere for Masha. Wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty goes back into the room and returns at once with a she thrusts at Levin.  KITTY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And bring the perfume bottle in the outside pocket of my handbag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes back into the room and doesn't return. Levin, hu the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai has been stripped. Masha washes his body. Kitty e arms full of clean linen.     156 LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai lies naked in clean sheets. Masha hauls him up in tion. Kitty puts a nightshirt over his head. Nikolai prot  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masha and Kitty pull the nightshirt over his body. Kitty over him. Masha adjusts the fresh pillow. She combs his h   LATER--NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai lies quietly in a neat bed in the neat room, with water jug, etc., tidily by the bed. Masha keeps vigil by his hand, singing to him quietly.  NIKOLAI (WHEEZING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin comes into the room he shared with his brother. The abandoned for years . . . two bare beds, a washstand, a w contains a jumble of books, shoes, a pair of skates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin hears sleigh bells arriving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sleigh draws up, bringing a Priest.   157

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin, feeling out of place, is at the washstand. He noti wrapped new cake of soap. He picks it up and puts it to h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masha and Kitty are kneeling by the bed. The Priest bends holding up an icon in front of Nikolai's face and murmuri Levin, embarrassed, puts down the soap and comes forward   LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai is at the point of death. Levin stares, torn betw and the lack of mystery, the ordinariness of the body fin The death rattle comes. Masha kisses the dead hand. The P to murmur. Kitty takes hold of Masha's hand. Levin stares face: if this is death, what is life?   LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai lies dead, candles burning at his head and feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levin counts money, for the services of the Priest . . . and soup.  LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Father . . . and how much . . . ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He offers a handful of paper money.     158 PRIEST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At your benevolence. It is a custom, not a levy, Your Excellency . . . Jesus overturned the money-tables outside the temple, but . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs and puts the money away, and returns to his sou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The snow is almost gone. Nikolai's grave has flowers stre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pava's yearling and several more calves, delirious with r yard with the herd, to pasture, with a Herdsman and Laska

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masha is leaving, alone behind the Coachman. She sits qui look back. Levin and Kitty watch her drive away.  KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're such an expert on love, Kostya . . . why didn't you know it when you saw it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia hurries along grand deserted hallways. She knows he ahead of her opens and a dozen Politicians and Civil Serv portfolios cross her path, with Stremov at the centre of sation. Stremov is smiling, triumphant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia expects to see Karenin among them. She hurries on t came from.   159

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Lydia enters, Karenin, alone in the chamber, is sitt defeated. He starts gathering his papers. Lydia comes to explained, she takes an opened letter from her bag.  LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexei, they're back! Here in St. Petersburg! She has written to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karenin accepts the letter and reads it.  KARENIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To you? . . . I think I don't have the right to refuse . . . It's the boy's birthday . . .  LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend . . . you would be blowing on the embers of a fire which must be allowed to die . . . Let me write to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is looking into the display window of a toy shop. Sh ing. She enters the shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Returning from the toy shop with a wrapped parcel, Anna c is stacked up in the hallway and Franz is unpacking stuff

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sees that a hand-delivered letter is waiting for her. the letter. For a moment she is devastated by it--but the   160

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very early morning. The street is not awake. A hired to her former home. She is heavily veiled, and carries th from the toy shop. The cab is to wait for her. She rings

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sleepy Servant opens the big wooden door.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here to see Sergei Alexeyich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young Servant doesn't know her. Anna steps past him, into his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kapitonich, pulling on his livery greatcoat, comes to the and lets Anna in. He does not recognise her.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have brought something for Sergei Alexeyich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kapitonich scrutinises her, prepared to forestall her.  KAPITONICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is not up yet. Would you wish to wait? Who shall I say . . . ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kapitonich peers at her and realises who she is. He steps  KAPITONICH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please come in, Your Excellency.   161

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna goes quickly to the stairs.  KAPITONICH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allow me to announce you. The tutor may be there and not dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna shakes her head and is almost running away from him. gives chase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAPITONICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please allow me!

dialogues.speaker: INT. UPPER LEVEL, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--
dialogues.text: DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna dashes past two Housemaids who gape at her, and disa the corner. She's a little mad now.

dialogues.speaker: INT. UPPER STAIRS, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--
dialogues.text: DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, wild-eyed, climbs the stairs and meets the tutor, V coming down, buttoning his waistcoat. Lukich is startled,  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've come to see Sergei Alexeyich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kapitonich reaches these stairs, calling, "Your Excellenc     162

dialogues.speaker: INT. TOP FLOOR, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--
dialogues.text: DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna dashes for Serozha's door and flings herself through

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no longer Serozha's room. A large Woman sits up in b the Cook. She cries out. Anna reels back. She looks panic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kapitonich catches up, out of breath.  KAPITONICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been moved to the small sitting room.

dialogues.speaker: INT. UPPER STAIRS, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--
dialogues.text: DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the bottom of the Upper Stairs, Lukich, the Housemaids half-dressed Footmen have their heads together. They move hurries by, seeing nothing.

dialogues.speaker: INT. UPPER LEVEL, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--
dialogues.text: DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kapitonich catches up with Anna at the door of the "small  KAPITONICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just look in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna shakes her head and walks past him, into the room.   163

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The curtains are drawn closed. The room is dim. Anna sees up, yawning, his eyes closed, and falling back on the pil the bed and whispers his name. Serozha raises himself on his eyes and smiles dreamily and falls forward into her a  SEROZHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my dear little boy.  SEROZHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you would come. Today is my birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serozha rubs his face on her neck, falls back on the pill and going back to sleep. Anna looks at him avidly, touchi his shoulders, the hair over his ears. She can't stop her awake.  SEROZHA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you crying?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't cry. It's time for you to get dressed. And I almost forgot your present, look . . . open it . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serozha takes off her hat.  SEROZHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want that . . . Let me see.    164

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serozha tears open the package, lifts the lid of the card a puppet, a beautifully dressed marionette.  SEROZHA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he's grand!

dialogues.speaker: INT. UPPER LEVEL, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--
dialogues.text: DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Korney, the Valet, among others, has joined the "conferen Kapitonich.  KORNEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your fault for letting her in!--you should be sacked.  KAPITONICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, you would have sent her packing! Ten years I've been keeping the door and the mistress was always kind to me. You should stick to stealing the master's clothes.  LUKICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had enough of this--it's my job to get the boy out of bed before His Excellency comes . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lukich cautiously opens the door. He sees mother and son pet and laughing quietly. Lukich backs off. Anna looks ro door closing.   165 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling Kutik, Maman can't stay . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serozha clings to Anna.  SEROZHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go!--he's not coming yet.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I must, and you must love Papa-- he's better than I am. When you're grown-up . . .  SEROZHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one in the whole world is better than you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Servants in a huddle look round at the sound of a doo ing footsteps round a blind corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no one in view when Karenin comes around the cor vants have vanished. He goes to Serozha's door. Anna come

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops, astonished. Anna looks at him boldly, then pull Karenin bows. Anna walks past him.     166

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna comes "home" from Karenin's house. The visit has cha sits down in her hat and coat. Annushka comes in.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Anya?  ANNUSHKA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's still asleep. Should I take your coat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna shakes her head.  ANNUSHKA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you feeling unwell, Madame?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sleeping.  ANNUSHKA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can send out for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna nods.   LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twilight. Anna appears not to have moved. The baby is hea another room. Anna's face remains set, but she reacts on coming in.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you in the dark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns on a gaslight.   167 VRONSKY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yashvin is going to call . . . you remember him. (about her clothes) Are you going out?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To where? To whom?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know what happened to you.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I told you yesterday . . . My brother . . .  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it take all day for you to meet your brother? Does he need you more than I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky sits next to her and puts his arms round her.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna shakes her head.  VRONSKY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well . . . Alexander agreed to everything. Mother's house in Moscow will go to him, and the country estate will be our new home . . . as soon as the divorce . . . Karenin hasn't answered your letter yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna shakes her head. She stands up at last and takes off   168

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yashvin is a welcome visitor.  YASHVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's wonderful to have you both returned.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How good you are to come. You're the very first person to call on me since our return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yashvin gets the point of that. He is embarrassed.  ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I received a note from Princess Betsy asking me if I'd call on her between six-thirty and eight. Or was it seven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yashvin got the point of that, too.  ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alas, between six-thirty and seven is just when I'm unable to see her!  YASHVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But perhaps you'll meet at the opera tonight?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would love to be there if I could get a box.  YASHVIN (BOWS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame, your box is number four! You'll find me there with Princess Myagkaya. Will you come, Vronsky?   169

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky shakes his head. Yashvin kisses Anna's hand.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see why . . . Alexei is so fond of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yashvin laughs and bows himself out.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know you can't go to the theatre?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annushka!  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For heaven's sake--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annushka comes.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bath. I'll come in and choose a dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annushka goes.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna--I implore you--don't you know . . . ?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not ashamed of who I am or what I've done: are you ashamed for me? Why do you keep a room at the hotel? Aren't we together? Have you changed towards me?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's because I love you and care about you.    170 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's the case, I don't know why you aren't coming with me.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would make it worse.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're afraid. Well, I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before the performance, the stairs, galleries and corrido to the stalls and boxes, are crowded with the town's high Anna, at her most beautiful, is magically cleaving throug of her presence is like a contagion, and yet everyone man eye . . . so while all around her there are people impedi greetings, Anna's path opens before her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knows what is happening. It shocks her but her eyes b The spell is broken by Princess Myagkaya (she of the 85 k hails her.  PRINCESS MYAGKAYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna . . . !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up on the surrounding effect of this, and rubs taking Anna's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: princess myagkaya (cont'd) Something has done you good--you look wonderful.     171

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky sits and broods. Angrily, he changes his mind. He ing for Franz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky's cab draws up outside the brightly lit, deserted alights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky comes up the stairs. The place is deserted, apart dants . . . one of whom takes Vronsky's cloak and gives h

dialogues.speaker: INT. ANNA'S BOX, OPERA HOUSE, SAME TIME--
dialogues.text: NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On stage, Act One is just ending, and the curtain falls. way to chatter.  PRINCESS MYAGKAYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should we visit or stay put?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna sees Vronsky entering on the side-aisle below. He lo boxes, seeking her. She turns away.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay put.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princess Myagkaya has engaged the attention of Stremov in ing box.   172 PRINCESS MYAGKAYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minister! Congratulations. Come in for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Stremov only bows coldly and turns away. Yashvin note begins to chew his moustache anxiously. Anna's neighbour a meek husband of a battle-axe, admires her openly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna sees that Vronsky has stopped to talk to Countess Vr Princesses Sorokina. The young Princess seems animated by bows himself away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princess Myagkaya sees where Anna is looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: princess myagkaya (cont'd) Princess Sorokina and her daughter, they're from Moscow, neighbours of Countess Vron- sky, quite well off, no sons, she's a widow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna gives her a smiling but wounded look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: princess myagkaya (cont'd) My dear, I'm a sales catalogue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky meets Alexander in the aisle and greets him.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll come up to see us afterwards . . . ?  ALEXANDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk to Varya.    173

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander indicates his seat to Vronsky. Vronsky sits by  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you call on Anna?  VARYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Alexei . . . I'm fond of you . . . but . . .  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake, Anna isn't a criminal!  VARYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd call on her if she'd only broken the law. But she broke the rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky is angry and offended. He gets up, bows to Varya. up, he sees Betsy beckoning to him from her box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna watches Vronsky, sees him acknowledge Betsy's summon  PRINCESS MYAGKAYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who has made the decor? Haven't we got a programme? Colonel, would you be so kind . . . ?  YASHVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's neighbour, emboldened, offers her his programme.     174 NEIGHBOUR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please . . . I would be honoured if you would take mine . . .  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, how very . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Neighbour's Wife, catching this, reacts as though ele

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princess Betsy is smoking. Prince Tverskoy is examining a Vronsky enters the box. He bows to the Prince, and kisses  PRINCE TVERSKOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catullus, printed in Venice, 1501 . . . remarkable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grovelling House Manager appears in their midst, to tel smoke in the box.  HOUSE MANAGER (BOWING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thousand apologies, Princess, but . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princess Betsy blows smoke and hands the cigarette, in it standing quietly in the shadowy corner of the box: Makhot takes the cigarette from the holder, crushes it in his le humiliated . . . but that's love. The House Manger bows a  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Makhotin . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Angry Wife's voice cuts through the audience chatter.   175 WIFE'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a disgrace! Take me home!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky turns round to look. He sees the Husband trying t  WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fetch my cloak!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky sees Anna looking straight ahead. Yashvin is eati

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scene next door is a social catastrophe for Anna, but Princess Myagkaya takes her hand. Yashvin shrinks into hi fied. The whole opera house is becoming aware of the "sca Wife has raised her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we coming to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Husband has succeeded in putting his wife's cloak ove Her exit line is for the benefit of the entire audience.  WIFE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this the opera house or a--or a French music hall-- ?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Wife and her Husband leave the box.     176

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky is tormented. He moves to leave the box.  BETSY (SARCASTIC)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, why don't you? Rescue her and put your seal on the fiasco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky knows it and is trapped.  BETSY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexei . . . you see why she must divorce. Marriage will solve everything. When will it be?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As far as I'm concerned, she's my wife.  BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, as you saw, she isn't.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to Moscow, and then to my place in the country.  BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds like a good idea.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But for a day or two, Anna will be at home, at my flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy shrugs.    177 VRONSKY (CONT'D) (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, I'll say goodbye now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angry and upset, Anna sweeps into the flat in her opera c follows her in.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . you had an excellent night! Does your mother want you to marry the widow or the child?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either one.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make a joke of it. If you loved me, you would have locked me in to stop me going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She throws aside her cloak and goes into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annushka, asleep in a chair, waiting loyally, wakes up.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky comes in as Annushka goes out. He comes to Anna a arms round her.    178 VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it was my fault.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't sleep.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how to make you sleep.  LATER--IN BED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky makes love to Anna but it's not working for her. around. By the bed is a carafe of water, an empty glass a bottle as dark as ink, with a handwritten label.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High summer. Heat and dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, with some dainty shopping by her, is taking tea in eye is caught by a mother and son at another table. The b Anna misses her son acutely in that moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Dolly enters the tea shop. Anna's heart lifts for a is about to greet her, but then realises that Dolly is on ladies," and Anna lowers her head. When she sneaks a look one of the ladies whispering to the others. Anna realises recognised by a stranger, and is notorious. She "hides" i money to leave on the table so that she can escape. A sou up and she sees that Dolly has sat down opposite her.    179 DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna . . . I am very glad to see you. Are you well? How is your little one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna nods, words won't come.  DOLLY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stiva wanted to invite you and Count Vron- sky to the house but it's impossible . . .  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.  DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no--you don't. Kitty and her husband are with us. She's in Moscow to have the baby.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty . . . ? Oh, tell her how pleased I am . . . !  DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I'll wait a year or two. (she gulps a laugh) Oh . . . love!  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes . . . love! Don't you disapprove of me for what I've done?  DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I wish I'd done the same. But no one asked me! Well . . . I wouldn't have been brave enough. (she blinks tears) Stiva, you know . . . he doesn't change . . . like all men, I suppose.   180

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't notice her tactlessness but it lands on Anna, smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, in a nightdress, is awake in the night, staring out window of a grand hotel, smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna comes back to bed. Vronsky is asleep. She unstops a (a different one) and pours a draught mixed with water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna sleeps alone in the bed. Annushka, after a tap on th cautiously, worried.  ANNUSHKA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame . . . Madame . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna sits up.  ANNUSHKA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you ill?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it? Is Anya up?     181 ANNUSHKA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's afternoon, Madame.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all right. It's all right. (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get them to bring up all our trunks and travel cases. We've been here long enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky comes in, noting the empty trunks and cases stack comes from her room to greet him. She is making an effort but she looks excited, febrile.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had an inspiration. Why do we have to wait here? Why can't we wait in the coun- try? I don't want to hear any more about a divorce, or think about it.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good! I'm bored here. When should we go?  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I bore you here, I'll bore you in the country.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say you bore me. Moscow bores me. When should we go? . . . Tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Anna's mood has turned.    182 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't be ready by tomorrow.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day after, then.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you like.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, wait. That's Sunday. I have to see Maman.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's twenty minutes away in the train-- you could go to see her tomorrow--or was it that you wanted to spend Sunday with Princess Sorokina?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't spoil everything. I can't see Maman tomorrow because she won't have read the papers she has to sign. Oh, and then there's the bank . . . But we can leave on Tuesday.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that case, let's not bother. I'll leave on Sunday or not at all.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's absurd!     183 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's absurd to you because you have no understanding for my life here.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna . . . Anna . . .  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've stopped loving me. You've given up everything for me, and it's turned you against me. Why lie about it?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop. I put off our departure for a day or two, and you tell me I don't love you.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I've been living off your love and there's none left, so this is over! Finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves him, slamming the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna comes in and lies down on the bed, closes her eyes, dose from the medicine bottle by the bed, and lies down. He takes her hand.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I don't mind when we go.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll telegraph Maman. We'll go on Sunday. I'll do anything you want.   184 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should leave me.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to. I love you.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't ask why about love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna comes straight from bed. She is drugged and shaky. T empty but there is a coffee tray on the table. Anna feels pours herself a cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky is at his desk. Anna enters with her coffee. Vron telegram. Seeing her enter, he puts the telegram under hi  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So--will you be all packed? I'll be out today making the arrangements.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that your way of telling me you'll be at your mother's with that simpering little princess?     185 VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'll be with my lawyers. I'm waiting for some documents. Then I'm having dinner to say goodbye to old comrades.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I know what that means.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, this is unendurable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He controls himself.  VRONSKY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can invite them here if you like.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, but if I'm not fit to dine in soci- ety, I won't eat with the band. Who was the telegram from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky retrieves the telegram and hands it to her.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't show it to you, because Stiva keeps telegraphing what we already know. Kare- nin promises nothing, but will consider . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna tosses the telegram aside unread.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you I don't care about the divorce, so why hide the telegram? What else do you hide from me?    186 VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hide nothing from you.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you care about the divorce? What has it got to do with us loving each other?  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until we're married, our daughter is legally Karenin's. I care about it because we need to be free to marry.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're perfectly free to marry anyone your mother wants.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we aren't talking about--  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we are, and, by the way, compared to your mother I'm the Virgin Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky is silent with anger. He gets up and goes out, re hat in his hand.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything you wish to say to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She remains silent. He leaves again. She lights a cigaret     187

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sorokina Coach draws up outside the door. The coach w and the Coachman's livery (a bright yellow cockade) are h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, with her cup of coffee, comes in and looks down fro   ANNA'S POV--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vronsky, hat in hand, at the coach window, accepts a larg lilac-gloved hand. He bows. With a wave of the hand and a hair, the coach pulls away. Vronsky goes back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the envelope, Vronsky comes in. Anna is as he left h stubbed out.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's the child.  VRONSKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She brought papers from Maman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hesitates, thinking she is about to speak.  VRONSKY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stays silent. He leaves.   188

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna finds Annushka filling several half-filled cases.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unpack everything. We're not going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lies down on the bed. Annushka would like to comfort  ANNUSHKA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna Arkadyeva . . .  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Count Vronsky comes back, tell him . . . I don't want to be disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is listening for Vronsky's return. She hears him com him approach. Then she hears Annushka's voice, then Vrons waits in suspense, disappointed as Vronsky's steps retrea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, holding a candle-lamp, finds Vronsky asleep on the tates, but turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna wakes. She re-collects herself. She looks at the bed den hurry she leaves the bed and the bedroom.    189

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME--DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna finds Annushka waiting.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Count Vronsky . . . ?  ANNUSHKA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He went out early, to the stables, he said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna collapses on a chair and weeps.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Annushka . . . I should have died. Do you remember?  ANNUSHKA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take it to heart, Anna Arkadyeva . . .  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've made him hate me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's hand writes in a hurry: "I'm to blame. Come home. frightened."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna seals the note and gives it to Annushka.     190 ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Michael to hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annushka runs out with the note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is keeping watch at the window . . . and is rewarded ing coach. She hurries out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna looks down into the entrance hall. Michael, the Coac and comes up the stairs to her. She sees that he is holdi  MICHAEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Count Vronsky had already left, Your Excel- lency. He took a cab to the station . . . to the Countess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna clutches her red bag to her, sitting among passenger

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna looks about her. Across the carriage she sees throug her train is overtaking another passenger train on the ne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at the windows of the other train "going by" . sengers inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unexpectedly, she seems to see a Man who might be Vronsky a laughing Woman who might be Princess Sorokina.   191

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's body jerks involuntarily. She half rises. The imag brief and is borne away, as her own train goes by, accele dows opposite pick up speed as she leaves them behind--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then she has the same illusion again-- a "Vronsky" an glimpsed in the other train and snatched away in the inst

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now she stands up and goes to the opposite window, where of the other train are flashing by in the (anachronistic) jected film-frames, and she sees "Vronskys" and "Sorokina gathering speed. And then the train has gone and there's but the view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna collapses into the nearest seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train arrives at a small station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna steps down from the train. The platform is well popu waiting to board the train or to meet the arriving passen energy about the people-- shouting, laughter, movement. P custom. A couple of Young Men seem to be laughing rudely but they pass by, ignoring her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna pauses, bewildered, lost, not knowing what to do nex

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sees the Sorokina Coachman on the platform, recognisi livery, a cockade in his hat.  ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you waiting for the Princess Sorokina?     192 COACHMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Your Excellency, both princesses are at the house of Countess Vronsky. I'm waiting FOR HIM--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna turns back, agitated, expecting Vronsky to appear, b is a Footman carrying three hatboxes and a large box from

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna walks away, along the platform, impeded by people go aware that some are staring at her as she passes. A Boy s at her. A little group of Ladies and Children meeting a b off the train are laughing and chattering but fall silent increases her pace. She hurries away towards the far end Beyond her, a goods train is slowly approaching. Between two Maidservants are walking towards her. They turn their at her, remarking on her dress.  MAIDSERVANT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that lace on her . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
